title: Kendall Lake Pier and Shelter
listingDescription: The Kendall Lake Pier was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps and originally served as a swimming pier. Today it serves as a fishing pier, a photography point, and a place to relax and enjoy nature.

images.altText: Informational panel on wide grass pier edged by wooden boardwalk; rustic shelter in the distance.
images.title: Kendall Lake Pier and Shelter
images.caption: A historic fishing pier extends out in front of the Kendall Lake Shelter.

bodyText:
People come to the Kendall Lake pier to fish, relax, and enjoy nature. While the spot feels very natural, people shaped what you see. The area has been logged and farmed. In the 1930s the Civilian Conservation Corps built a dam to create the lake, planted thousands of trees, and added the adjacent shelter as a bathhouse.

The lake flooded a spot where two streams come together to become the main branch of Salt Run. Nearby seeps and springs suggest that a large wetland complex once existed here. This natural water source may have helped the CCC select the location for the lake.

The CCC followed designs that fit into the natural landscape. The shelter, for example, seems to grow out of the hillside. How natural does this spot feel to you?
audioDescription: Kendall Lake Pier and Shelter. 365 words This wayside graphic panel sits at the end of a wide pier that extends out into the small lake. As you face the panel the earthen pier stretches away from you back to the shore. All three sides of the pier are edged with wooden boardwalks. Several benches sit on the boardwalks and a picnic table sits in the middle of the grass-covered pier itself. At the end of the pier is a two-story stone building with open doorways leading to the lower floor and cement steps on either side leading to the second floor with its wide covered porch along the front. The lake stretches in the other three directions, an earthen dam located over your right shoulder. The edges of the lake are marshy with large stands of cattails. The entire area is wooded. Text at the top of the graphic panel reads, “Engineering Nature. Many of America’s parks were designed using naturalistic landscape principles developed in the early 1900s. The Kendall Lake area is an example of this design approach. Its idyllic setting was no accident. Once logged and farmed, the Kendall Lake landscape was molded by the Civilian Conservation Corps, or CCC, into the park you see today. CCC crews built a dam to create the lake, planted thousands of trees throughout the area, and built a bathhouse which seemed to grow out of the hillside.” At bottom left of the panel is a photograph looking down the pier from roughly your current position. Instead of a building backed by trees, there is a bare hillside with a couple of trucks at the left. The caption reads, “Kendall Lake beach area before bathhouse construction, circa 1935. Park architects designed the bathhouse to fit into this landscape.” On the right side is a smaller photograph with an aerial view of the Kendall Lake Bathhouse circa 1937. It shows the pier, small figures of people around its edges, and the two-story bathhouse set back from its end. Many more figures are in the water to the right and on a beach which lies to the right of the pier. Today the former beach area is covered in grass. End of description.

quickFacts.value: 1000 Truxell Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Kendall Lake and the adjacent bathhouse are centerpieces of a recreational landscape built by the Civilian Conservation Corps during the Great Depression in the 1930s.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Virginia Kendall State Park Historic District; Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Kendall Lake Trailhead Information
listingDescription: The Kendall Lake is one of the many amenities the Civilian Conservation Corps built in the Virginia Kendall Park. A one-mile trail loops around Kendall Lake. The Cross Country and Salt Run trails can also be accessed from this location.

images.altText: Paved path leads past bulletin board and graphic panel to lake with pier; shelter and woods beyond.
images.title: Kendall Lake Trailhead
images.caption: Kendall Lake has a picnic shelter, fishing pier, outside exhibits, and a network of trails.

bodyText:
Coal industrialist Hayward Kendall willed his private retreat, later named Virginia Kendall Park, to the people of Ohio following his death in 1927. The Civilian Conservation Corps built Kendall Lake in 1934-1935 by damming Salt Run. At the time Akron Metropolitan Park District (now Summit Metro Parks) managed the property. For years, people flocked here in the summer for the swimming beach and in the winter for the toboggan run and ice skating. Today’s national park visitors come to fish and enjoy nearby trails.

The paved path beyond the bulletin board leads to Kendall Lake Shelter and a fishing pier. Public restrooms with running water are available on the lower level of the shelter.

Trails start to the left of the bulletin board. The Lake Trail is a one-mile loop around the lake. It is a mostly flat trail with a dirt surface and some stairs to climb. The trail offers views of the lake and opportunities to enjoy plants and wetlands along its edge. You might find beaver activity and other signs of wildlife.

Cross Country Trail also begins to the left of the bulletin board. This 2.5-mile loop has a dirt surface and 160 feet of elevation change. Access Salt Run Trail near the dam along the Lake Trail. Salt Run is a 3.25-mile loop with a dirt surface and 160 feet of elevation change. Both trails wander through wooded ravines. Cross Country Trail also takes you through an old farm field that is becoming forest through natural succession. This trail is popular with cross country skiers who have the skill to handle hills.
audioDescription: Kendall Lake Trailhead. 455 words Here at the corner of the parking lot is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. Along the right side of the kiosk a paved path leads through a grassy area towards a pier which extends out into the small lake. Opposite the pier is a stone building. Directly behind you as you face the kiosk is a wayside graphic panel titled, “Honest Work.” The parking lot stretches to your left and behind you. The parking lot is edged with stone posts, one-foot square and ranging in height from one to two feet. Past the left side of the kiosk, the pavement leads to an unpaved path that enters the woods. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the middle of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place of retreat from urban life. Building on this tradition, citizens worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked Earth Day and the Clean Water Act. “Coal industrialist Hayward Kendall willed his private retreat, later named Virginia Kendall Park, to the people of Ohio following his death in 1927. The Civilian Conservation Corps built Kendall Lake in 1934-35 for recreational use. For years, people flocked here for the swimming beach, toboggan run, and ice skating. Today’s visitors come to fish, rent snowshoes and cross-country skis, and enjoy nearby trails.” Text at the top of the wayside graphic reads, “The guard posts circling the parking lot are a result of the ‘honest work’ President Franklin D. Roosevelt believed the Civilian Conservation Corps, or CCC, would provide young unemployed Americans. Conceived under Roosevelt’s New Deal, the CCC put 250,000 young men to work rebuilding the country during the Great Depression. For the guard post project, corpsmen were taught how to quarry local Berea Sandstone and shape it into 3-foot by 1-foot by 1-foot posts. These posts were then ‘planted’ around most area parking lots. Over 1,000 guard posts were paced around the roads and parking lots of Virginia Kendall Park. The project achieved three major CCC goals: developing the nation’s park areas; teaching vocational skills; and providing work for young men.” At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of the young men at work installing the guard posts. Next to the photo is an engineer’s drawing showing that most of the 3-foot height of the posts was buried in the ground. End of description.

title: Ledges Overlook
listingDescription: The Ledges Overlook provides an expansive view of the Cuyahoga Valley. From here, visitors can appreciate how the park protects a large tract of natural open space between the cities of Akron and Cleveland. The scenery is stunning in any season.

images.altText: View from a rocky ledge looking out at a sunset over fall treetops.
images.title: Ledges Overlook at Sunset
images.caption: Ledges Overlook is a favorite spot for sunsets and fall colors.

bodyText:
The Ledges Overlook looks west over an expansive view of the Cuyahoga Valley. The bare rock of the Ledges provides a natural viewing platform. From here, visitors can appreciate how the park protects a large tract of forested open space between the cities of Akron and Cleveland. The scenery is stunning in any season.

The Ledges Overlook is a stop on the Ledges Trail. This 1.8-mile trail loops around this outcropping of Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate. The up-close views of the rocks from the trail contrast with the broad view from the overlook.

Learn more about the geology of the Cuyahoga Valley.
audioDescription: Ledges Overlook. 117 words Here at the edge of a steep hillside is a rocky outcrop. The rocks lie in large slabs to form a natural viewing platform looking west over the deciduous forest below. On either side and behind the outcropping are more woods, this area having hemlocks mixed in. The rocks on the left side as you face outward have eroded to form a rough stair step configuration. This becomes more irregular near the edge of the steep hillside, with channels cut at irregular intervals. Down below the treetops rise to just below the top of the ledge. The view stretches out over the tree-covered valley to end at a low ridge in the distance. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Ledges Trailhead, 405 Truxell Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Hike the Ledges Trail to the Overlook or use a trail map to shortcut across the playfield.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ledges Overlook is one of the more photographed locations within Cuyahoga Valley National Park and is within the Virginia Kendall State Park Historic District.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Virginia Kendall State Park Historic District; Designated Scenic Overlook; Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Ledges Shelter and Exhibits
listingDescription: The Ledges Shelter is the largest Civilian Conservation Corps shelter in Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Groups and families with up to 75 people may reserve it for a fee.

images.altText: Graphic panel along a paved path to a rustic shelter; rows of picnic tables under its roofed porch.
images.title: Ledges Shelter and Exhibits
images.caption: Ledges Shelter has one graphic panel along the walkway and another by the main door.

bodyText:
The 1930s Great Depression had left millions unemployed and desperate. In response to the crisis, President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the Civilian Conservation Corps, or CCC. The Ledges Shelter is a product of this back-to-work program.

The men employed by the CCC often came with no skills and little work experience. The CCC provided employment, education, and training. At the same time, it left the nation with new parks, forests, roads, and facilities for outdoor recreation. Locally, the sweat and effort of those young men created this retreat for all to enjoy.

Today, the Ledges Shelter may be reserved at recreation.gov by groups and families with up to 75 people for a fee. The shelter includes an enclosed area with two fireplaces, eight picnic tables, and an area to serve food. Electrical outlets for normal, two-pronged household appliances such as coffee pots and crock pots are available. It does not have centralized heat. The building’s open pavilion has eight additional picnic tables and a large grill. Drinking water is available at a fountain from May 1 to September 15. Restrooms with flush toilets are available year-round.

Ledges Shelter is constructed from local Berea sandstone and wormy chestnut, wood from American chestnut trees that had been killed by a blight. The CCC paid attention to the placement of buildings, as well as their design. A large grassy playfield sits next to and in harmony with Ledges Shelter. It invites people to run around, toss a ball, and enjoy the expansive outdoors.
audioDescription: Ledges Shelter. 438 words This wayside graphic panel faces a flagstone-paved patio sheltered by a long roof extending out towards us. A small stone building is at the far end of the shelter with another graphic panel on the wall there between sets of French doors. Under the shelter are two lines of picnic tables. Restrooms are located at the back of the building. As you face the panel to your right is a paved path leading from the parking lot behind you to the shelter. To the left is a wide, grassy lawn. At the top of the wayside panel is a quote from Franklin Delano Roosevelt which reads, “The overwhelming majority of unemployed Americans, who are now walking the streets and receiving private or public relief, would infinitely prefer to work. We can take a vast army of these unemployed out into healthful surroundings. We can eliminate to some extent at least the threat that enforced idleness brings to spiritual and moral stability.” Text to the right reads, “The Great Depression had left millions unemployed and desperate. In response to the crisis, President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the Civilian Conservation Corps, or CCC. The Ledges Shelter, before you, is a product of this back-to-work program.” The bottom of the panel has photographs of young men working, positioning heavy wooden beams on top of posts and pouring concrete. One photo shows a large group posing in front of a bare work site. Alongside the photographs are several quotes on the CCC building program in the Virginia Kendall area from the shelter’s architect, a CCC supervisor, and the Director-Secretary of the Akron Metropolitan Park District in 1934. The graphic panel on the wall of the shelter is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the eastern edge of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Coal industrialist Hayward Kendall willed his private retreat, later named Virginia Kendall Park, to the people of Ohio following his death in 1927. Managed by different agencies over the years, the park gave area residents more space for recreation and play. Most of the Virginia Kendall structures were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s.” End of description.

title: Ledges Trailhead Information
listingDescription: The striking rock cliffs of the Ledges are a primary feature of Virginia Kendall Park, developed in the 1930s. Use this trailhead to access a 1.8-mile trail that circles the Ledges, a rentable shelter, a giant grassy playfield, and many wooded picnic sites.

images.altText: A two sided bulletin board along a paved road; a “Ledges” sign just below the peaked roof.
images.title: Ledges Trailhead Kiosk
images.caption: This trailhead bulletin board is by the gated access road to Ledges Shelter.

bodyText:
The striking rock Ledges create a plateau at a high point in the Cuyahoga Valley uplands. The Ledges Trailhead sits on the top of the plateau. The connector trail behind the bulletin board leads to the 1.8-mile Ledges Trail. It circles the plateau and provides stunning views of the Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate rock formation.

This area was part of the Ritchie Farm in the 1800s. Cleveland industrialist Hayward Kendall purchased the farm for a private retreat. Upon his death in 1927, he willed it to the people as a place for outdoor recreation. It became a state park named for Hayward’s mother, Virginia Kendall.

Akron Metropolitan Park District (now Summit Metro Parks) took over operation of the park during the Great Depression. The park district recruited the Civilian Conservation Corps to develop the park. Crews built the parking, trails, shelters, and large grassy playfield. It became part of Cuyahoga Valley National Park after 1974.

Today, visitors can walk the trails and then linger at the many wooded picnic sites. The Ledges Shelter is available to rent for family reunions and other events. The grassy playfield invites running, kite flying, and other fun.
audioDescription: Ledges Trailhead. 275 words This covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel sits along a wide, paved path which is a continuation of the Ledges Road which provides automobile access to this area. The path then passes the Ledges Shelter on the left and heads into the woods. As you face the kiosk the parking lot lies over your left shoulder. The shelter with its restrooms may be reached by a path at the left end of the parking lot or by passing the kiosk and turning left to cross the grassy lawn. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the eastern edge of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Coal industrialist Hayward Kendall willed his private retreat, later named Virginia Kendall Park, to the people of Ohio following his death in 1927. Managed by different agencies over the years, the park gave area residents more space for recreation and play. Most of the Virginia Kendall structures were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s.” The bulletin board to the right of the panel has maps showing the network of looping trails available near this point. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Ledges Trailhead, 405 Truxell Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Walk to the gated service drive by the shelter.

title: Lock 26
listingDescription: Lock 26 was one of 44 locks that let canal boats step up from Lake Erie to the 968-foot-high Portage Summit in Akron. The Carter family lived nearby and had a dairy farm in addition to working on the Ohio & Erie Canal. Here in the Cuyahoga Valley, dairy farming was common, and the area became known as “cheesedom.” An exhibit at Lock 26 explores the Carter family story and local cheesemaking.

images.altText: A pale gray trail to the right of and parallel to a stone canal lock and graphic panel.
images.title: Lock 26 and Wayside
images.caption: The Towpath Trail runs by Lock 26, just south of the Beaver Marsh boardwalk.

bodyText:
Forty-four locks allowed boats on the Ohio & Erie Canal to stair-step up from Lake Erie to the Portage Summit in Akron. Families and businesses clustered at these locks. Charles and Susan Carter lived near Lock 26.

Canal, farm, railroad – all played a part in the lives of the Carters. Charles served as a canal boat captain and locktender. The family raised corn and hay on their 56-acre farm to feed their dairy cows. A short walk would take them to the former community of Ira, located near today’s Ira and Riverview roads. Though the community did not have any stores, taverns, or churches, it was a distribution point for dairy products. The Carters and other local farmers brought milk to the Hawkins Cheese Factory for processing. It was one of many in the region, which became known as ‘Cheesedom.’ From the community’s railroad depot, farmers shipped their cheese and fresh milk to urban areas.

While at Lock 26, view the exhibit to explore an early “selfie” by Edwin Bell Howe. He was taking the image of himself with his new safety bicycle. Yet note in the background the number of wooden cheese hoops, full of cheese, waiting to be shipped out this spring morning.
audioDescription: Lock 26. 453 words This wayside graphic panel is near the left end of the old lock, its walls at ground level near the path. There is water in the bottom of the lock and in the canal at either end. Lily pads are prevalent at the right end of the lock. Behind you on the other side of the path are wetlands. Trees line either side of the path. To the left of the panel is a backless bench. Along the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile with braille labels of the lock system. The edges of the profile can be sharp. Lake Erie at 573 feet is at the right end. Forty-four locks form stair steps up to the 968-foot-high Portage Summit at the left end. In between are Boston near Lock 32, Peninsula near Lock 29, and Mustill Store at Lock 15. Your current position at Lock 26 is near the middle of the profile. Text on the panel reads, “Life in Cheesedom. Canal, farm, railroad – all played a part in the lives of Charles and Susan Carter. They lived in a house next to Lock 26 and made a living in various ways. Charles served as a canal boat captain and locktender. The family also raised corn and hay on their 56-acre farm to feed their dairy cows. Though the community did not have any stores, taverns, or churches, Ira was a distribution point for dairy products. The Carters and other local farmers brought milk to the Hawkins Cheese Factory for processing. It was one of many in the region, which became known as ‘Cheesedom.’ From the nearby railroad depot, farmers shipped their cheese and fresh milk to urban areas.” In the middle of the panel is a black and white photograph of a small, two-story house next to a dirt path. The caption reads, “Charles and Susan Carters house bordered the canal towpath at Lock 26. Their son Darwin lived next door and helped run the family dairy farm.” At upper right is an image of a receipt from Hawkins Cheese Factory dated July 1901. “Farmers were paid every month for the milk they sold to the cheese factory.” Below that is a photograph of a man wearing a vest and hat. He stands on a depot platform, holding a bicycle next to him. Stacks of round boxes sit at the left side of the depot. The caption reads, “In this self-portrait, photographer Edwin Bell Howe stands at the railroad depot with stacks of cheese wheels. The depot was across from the cheese factory at the intersection of Ira and Riverview roads. The depot was named for Ira Hawkins, whose land was crossed by the tracks.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Ira Trailhead, 3801 Riverview Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Turn left and walk north on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Businesses and family homes clustered near locks on the Ohio & Erie Canal. The Carter family, who lived near Lock 26, contributed to Cuyahoga Valley’s reputation as “cheesedom.”
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Lock 29 River Access
listingDescription: Access the river from the Lock 29 Trailhead parking lot in Peninsula. Peninsula Depot and food are nearby.

images.altText: A gravel path lined with large rocks and trees leads to the river. To the left is an information pan
images.title: Lock 29 River Access
images.caption: A new access route from the parking lot at Lock 29 Trailhead to the river was built in 2023.

bodyText:
This site is downtown in the historic Village of Peninsula, a gateway to Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Put-in below the waterfall. More information is available at the Cuyahoga River Water Trail website.

Things to Know for Paddlers

  • Paved parking lot plus overflow gravel lot, restrooms, drinking water, restaurants and snacks within walking distance, hiking and biking trail, train station.
  • Parking is limited during peak hours.
  • Visitor information is at Trail Mix Peninsula.
  • Dropoff/pickup 50 feet from water’s edge over rocky ground
  • Shuttle option on Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad during Bike Aboard season. Fee. Board downstream at Brecksville Station (or Rockside Station), and ride to Peninsula Depot. Paddle back to Station Road Bridge Trailhead (or Lock 39 Trailhead).
  • Pedal/paddle option. Use the Towpath Trail to bike/run/walk back from trailheads as far downstream as Lock 39.
  • Initial Class II flow settles nicely into Class I after ½ mile with no permanent hazards to Boston Store Trailhead.

Known Hazards

Upstream:

  • Above the Lock 29 access site are the remains of a historic mill beside a natural waterfall. Do not paddle through the mill race on river left. At the waterfall, stay away from the dam remnant on river right. To avoid these hazards, portage left near the Main Street (SR 303) bridge.
audioDescription: Lock 29 River Access. 187 words The Cuyahoga River Water Trail access at Lock 29 is located on the northeast bank of the river. The path to the river access starts along the south border of the trailhead parking lot. It is rocky with a minor slope to the riverbank. A sign to the left has paddler information and hazards. When you reach the access point, the river will be in front of you. The access point has large rocks leading into the water with a large tree on either side. The river flows towards you before turning right under a pedestrian bridge for the Towpath Trail. Peninsula Depot is visible in the distance to the left. The Lock 29 restrooms are visible through the trees if you turn left. The back of river trail sign is also to the left. The front of the sign is dark blue with the Cuyahoga River Water Trail logo and “Lock 29 Trailhead.” Underneath the text is a lighter blue shaded area with the number “29.0” indicating the river mile. The terrain is uneven and made up of large rocks. End Description

quickFacts.value: Park at Lock 29 Trailhead, 1648 Mill Street, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Follow the marked path to the river.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Provides paddlers with access to the Cuyahoga River Water Trail
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Cuyahoga River Water Trail
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Lock 29 Trailhead Information
listingDescription: The Ohio & Erie Canal made Peninsula a busy industrial town and popular overnight stop for canal travelers. Today visitors can stroll through the historic downtown, shop, and dine. Lock 29 Trailhead is a popular, often crowded access point for the village, Towpath Trail, Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad, and Cuyahoga River Water Trail. On the towpath, travel 2.3 miles north to the village of Boston. About a mile south is Deep Lock and connecting trails to old stone quarries.

images.altText: Three sided kiosk beside parking lot posts. A paved path leads to a stone lock and wooded trail.
images.title: Lock 29 Trailhead Kiosk
images.caption: This kiosk provides arrival information for people using the Towpath Trail.

bodyText:
The Ohio & Erie Canal made Peninsula a busy industrial town and popular overnight stop for canal travelers. The village had boatyards, mills, hotels, taverns, and other businesses. Lock 29 Trailhead is a popular, often crowded access point for the village and Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail. It also provides parking for Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad and the Cuyahoga River Water Trail.

The trailhead is named for canal Lock 29. The path beyond the kiosk lets you walk into the lock. Exhibits explain the lock and an aqueduct that once carried the canal over the Cuyahoga River. On the towpath, travel 2.3 miles north to the historic village of Boston. About a mile south is Deep Lock and connecting trails to old stone quarries.

The railroad arrived in 1880. Its construction removed one of the curves of the Cuyahoga River to reduce the need for bridges. Peninsula Depot now serves Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad passengers. The walkway near the trailhead entrance drive leads to the depot.

The walkway also leads to Peninsula’s restaurants and shops. The area was settled originally as Connecticut’s Western Reserve. Stroll the village to enjoy New England-style architecture. As you browse, you might find yourself in a former bar, hotel, or immersed in a story of times past.

At the trailhead, paddlers can use a put-in for the Cuyahoga River Water Trail. The Buckeye Trail, a long-distance trail that circles Ohio, passes through the trailhead. Follow the blue blazes through town to go north or head south using the Towpath Trail.

Late in the late 1800s, residents of the cities of Cleveland and Akron discovered the valley as a place for respite and relaxation. Today, Peninsula is a haven for cyclists, hikers, runners, paddlers, birders, and history buffs.
audioDescription: Lock 29 Trailhead. 428 words A three-sided, covered kiosk with a bulletin board and two graphic panels sits at the edge of the parking lot to the left of a sidewalk that leads to the Towpath Trail and more exhibits at Lock 29. As you face the kiosk, the river bend is to the left. Restrooms are located in a small building on the other side of the parking lot near the train tracks. One of the graphic panels is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location in the middle of the park marked. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Lock 29 Trailhead. The Ohio and Erie Canal made Peninsula a busy industrial town and popular overnight stop for canal travelers. The village had boatyards, mills, hotels, taverns, and other businesses. Today visitors can stroll through the historic downtown and stop to shop and dine. Travel 2.3 miles north on the towpath to the historic village of Boston. About a mile south is Deep Lock and connecting trails to old stone quarries.” The third side has a panel titled “Ohio and Erie Canalway” with a large black and white photograph of three mules pulling a canal boat on the canal. Smaller photographs show the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad, a group of children riding bicycles on the towpath, and the scenic byway that winds through the valley. A long map down the right side shows mileage between trailheads on the Towpath Trail. Text on the panel reads, “The Ohio and Erie Canalway celebrates the first 110 miles of a waterway that helped the nation grow. Dug by hand from 1825 to 1832, the Ohio and Erie Canal was the first canal west of the Appalachian Mountains. It connected Lake Erie to the Ohio River, providing a key link in an interstate shipping route. People and products flowed across America. Canal towns became major commercial centers. Ohio grew in population and wealth. Today you can explore the lasting impact of this historic public works project. Travel along the Canalway’s three spines. Discover how culture, recreation, and natural scenic beauty are being revitalized by this national heritage area.” End of description.

quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ohio & Erie Canal made Peninsula a busy industrial town and popular overnight stop for canal travelers. Lock 29 continues to be a popular jumping-off point for exploring Cuyahoga Valley National Park and the Ohio & Erie Canalway.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Lock 32
listingDescription: Lock 32 was one of 44 locks on the Ohio & Erie Canal between Lake Erie in Cleveland and the Portage Summit in Akron. Historically, McBride’s Grocery served canallers at Lock 32.

images.altText: A trail to the left of a canal lock's cement walls; a wooden footbridge crosses over the far end.
images.title: Lock 32 Ohio & Erie Canal
images.caption: The footbridge over Lock 32 in Boston connects to the Valley Trail.

bodyText:
Locks were the highway interchanges of the Canal Era. While locks and highway interchanges have different functions, both help travelers through key transitions. Interchanges allow cars to enter and exit a highway. Locks allow boats to move up and down through changes in elevation. Lock 32 was one of 44 locks on the Ohio & Erie Canal between Lake Erie in Cleveland and the Portage Summit in Akron.

As with highway interchanges, locks became places where businesses concentrated. Locks forced travelers to pause for a minimum of 20 minutes while a boat locked through. This wait provided time to visit local businesses. McBride’s Grocery served canallers at Lock 32.

With the opening of the canal, Boston boomed. It grew from a small frontier hamlet to a bustling canal town. In time, stores, a tavern, hotel, blacksmith shop, boatyard, brickyard, lumberyard, broom factory, and warehouses would grow in the village.

Boston is still a lived-in village, as evidenced by the houses to the west. Go up the steps and over the top of the lock to access the Valley Trail or continue exploring the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail to the north or south. The heart of the village of Boston lies less than a tenth of a mile to the south.
audioDescription: Lock 32. 309 words This wayside graphic panel is near the right end of the lock walls, which are all that remain. This end of the lock is partially filled allowing access to the inside where the walls can be felt. Inside, the ground slopes down to the other end of the lock where the ground is marshy and may have standing water and higher vegetation. The left end of the lock has a wooden bridge with railings spanning the width giving closer views of that end. Text on the panel reads, “Boston Booms. The opening of the Ohio and Erie Canal turned Boston, a modest frontier settlement, into a thriving village. Between 1828 and 1836, increasing canal traffic sparked the opening of businesses. They included a blacksmith shop, hotel, tavern, two general stores, boatyard, brickyard, lumber mill, broom factory, and warehouse. McBride’s Grocery served canallers waiting to pass through Lock 32.” The right side of the panel has a black and white photograph of McBride’s Grocery next to Lock 32 with the Boston Store in the distance as the view would have been looking right from your current location. The buildings are white wood-frame with two stories. The lock gate is closed, some water spilling underneath it into the bottom of the lock while the water beyond is at a higher level. An arrow highlights the bare sandstone blocks on the walls of the lock, indicating that the photo was taken before 1905. Along the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile of the stairstep locks from the 968-foot high Portage Summit at Lock 1 at the right end and Lake Erie at 573-foot-elevation at the left end. You are currently at Lock 32 at Boston, to the left of the mid-point. As you explore the lock profile be careful of sharp corners on the stair steps. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Boston Trailhead, 1508 Boston Mills Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. (Accessible parking at Boston Store Trailhead.) Walk north on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Boston is typical of many small frontier hamlets that boomed because of the Ohio & Erie Canal. Businesses that concentrated at locks such as Lock 32 contributed to the bustling economy.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio and Erie Canal District; Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area; Ohio to Erie Trail; Industrial Heartland Trail Network, Boston Mills Historic District
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Lock 35
listingDescription: Read about the “laughter and tears” of the Murphy family who once had a farm at Lock 35.
bodyText: The Ohio and Erie Canal was once a vital transportation route, connecting Ohio to growing cities on the East Coast. To manage water flow, locks such as this one were built the length of the canal. They functioned like hydraulic elevators, raising and lowering canal boats.The Murphy family had a farm at Lock 35. For two centuries, farming was the main occupation throughout the valley. Small farms such as theirs shipped products out on the canal. Paul Murphy wrote several essays describing the “laughter and tears” of growing up here. The graphic panel includes quotes and images shared by his descendants.
audioDescription: Lock 35. 288 words The towpath here runs through quiet woods. The canal bed is dry and the lock is mostly filled with dirt, leaving a grassy area inside and on either side of the remaining low, stone walls. The inside of the lock may be reached from either end. Touch the walls inside to feel the weathered blocks. Text on the small wayside graphic panel reads, “Laughter and Tears. ‘There was no electricity, no running water,’ Paul Murphy recalled about growing up on a farm just south of here in the early 1900s. ‘In winter our house was heated by a stove in the living room and a cook stove in the kitchen. Homemade bread, biscuits, and pies were made from the flour that we brought back from the Wilson mill. Many a joyful trip was made in the sleigh behind our faithful horse, with the music of bells to accompany the songs we sang. The canal was a favorite spot for skating parties of people of all ages. We had our full share of both pleasure and frustration, of laughter and tears.’” At bottom left is a small black and white photograph of Paul and his mother Emma. It shows a gray-haired woman with wire-rimmed glasses and a dark-haired man. The caption tells us that Paul wrote about his memories in a manuscript entitled “Treasures of the Valley, A True Experience.” The right side of the panel shows a 1939 painting of the Murphy farmhouse by Maude McKisson, Paul’s sister-in-law. The winter scene looks south with the canal running along the left and a small log house sitting at the right. The banks are snow covered and the scene is lit only by a full moon. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Cross the bridge and walk south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Locks such as this one raised and lowered boats traveling along the Ohio & Erie Canal. In its day, this vital transportation route connected Ohio farms with hungry East Coast cities. Murphy family archives reveal what farm life was like here in the early 1900s.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Lock 36
listingDescription: By the remains of Lock 36, visitors can explore the Pinery Feeder which still “feeds” water from the Cuyahoga River into this section of the Ohio & Erie Canal.

images.altText: A graphic panel with a brown, arched metal footbridge over a watered channel in the background.
images.title: Lock 36 Panel
images.caption: Although little remains of Lock 36, the Pinery Feeder is still used to water the canal.

bodyText:
Shortly after the Ohio & Erie Canal opened in 1827, engineers realized more water was needed to maintain a constant four-foot level. They built the low-head Pinery Dam in the Cuyahoga River to direct water into a channel to “feed” the canal at Lock 36. This part of the valley is known as the Pinery Narrows because this skinny section once had abundant pine trees.

Canal locks such as this one once raised and lowered canal boats, acting like water-filled elevators. They were made of carved sandstone and lined (or “puddled”) with clay to keep them from leaking. But water takes its toll. Construction of the arched high-level bridge nearby also added to the debris in Lock 36.

From here visitors can go north or south on the Towpath Trail. A half-mile north, a horse trail veers off to the left. A short distance south, a connector trail leads to the Station Road Bridge Trailhead with exhibits, restrooms, drinking water, and a train station.
audioDescription: Lock 36. 376 words This wayside graphic panel is located near a fork in the path where a side trail separates from the Towpath Trail and loops to the west along the river. As you face the panel, the fork is to the left. The river is behind you. The Towpath Trail crosses a footbridge in front of you which goes over a channel of water. The channel runs from the river at the right and connects with the canal downstream at the left. The canal runs along the base of a wooded slope on the far side of the Towpath Trail. Text on the panel reads, “Feeding the Canal. Soon after this canal section opened in 1827, engineers built the Pinery Dam and Brecksville Feeder. This channel carries water from the Cuyahoga River into the canal at Lock 36. Originally the additional water maintained a proper depth for canal boats. Today this feeder provides water to the longest intact section of the Ohio and Erie Canal, a national historic landmark.” At the lower left is a 1907 photograph taken from the large hill to your left. It shows three channels of water – the Cuyahoga River on the right, the Ohio and Erie Canal on the right and the Brecksville Feeder on an angle connecting the two. The caption reads, “On the far side of today’s trail bridge, notice the remnants of Lock 36. The lock chamber was filled when the Brecksville-Northfield High-Level Bridge was built in the 1930s.” The right side of the panel is filled with a 1900 photograph of a team of three horses waiting to resume towing a boat in Lock 36. They stand at the left with a man on the towpath. A boat sits in the canal which runs down the right side of the picture. A small building is on the right side of the canal and a hillside rises steeply in the background. The slope has far fewer trees compared to today. At the top of the panel is a quote from the Ohio Canal Division Reports, 1880, which reads, “The dam and feeder are said to be in good condition. This furnishes all the extra water needed between this point and Cleveland and has always been ample.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Cross the bridge and walk north on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ohio & Erie Canal was once a vital transportation route, connecting Ohio to growing cities on the East Coast. Engineers built locks such as this one to raise and lower boats. Here the Pinery Feeder provides water to the longest intact section of the Ohio & Erie Canal, a national historic landmark.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, Valley Line National Heritage District
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Lock 37 and Flood Gate
listingDescription: Lock 37 was once a busy location with a tavern, mill and floodgate. A small parking lot on nearby Fitzwater Road provides access to the Towpath Trail.

images.altText: Two people walk a paved trail, pausing to read graphic panels. On the left is a water-filled canal w
images.title: 20181023 TTW-L37 wayside NPS Arrye Rosse
images.caption: Lock 37, on left, and a flood gate, on right, with Alexander/Wilson Mill in the background.

bodyText: Wherever a lock was built, boats had to stop to lock through. Businesses often sprang up at these spots, making use of the stopped traffic or the power of the falling water. Here at Lock 37, there was a tavern and a store. During the mid-1800s, the Alexanders built a mill across from this tavern. In time, that mill was sold to the Wilson family, who still own the business today. Regulating a constant four feet of water in the canal is a challenge. From the beginning, engineers struggled with too much or too little water. Near this busy lock is a flood gate that allows excess water to be released from the canal into the nearby Cuyahoga River. Even today this lock remains busy—being near the Towpath Trail, the Wilson Feed Mill, and the access road to the Fitzwater Trainyard.
audioDescription: Audio Description. Lock 37 and Water Control Gate. 432 words. At this point on the Towpath Trail near the concrete marker for mile 14 there are two small graphic wayside panels. On the canal side is one titled “Lock 37” which sits next to the old lock which has water at its bottom. The sides of the lock are weathered, worn concrete covering the upper part and the underlying blocks visible below. The gates are gone, but there is a stationary barrier, stone at the bottom, wooden beams above, which blocks the downstream end. There is no guardrail at the edge of the 10-foot-deep lock. The graphic panel features an artist’s illustration of a freight boat in the lock in 1863. A large white building beyond the lock on the left is the Alexander/Wilson Mill, still there today partially hidden by trees. The illustration shows several buildings on the right, now gone, which were the Vanoucek tavern, store, house and barn. Text on the panel reads, “Family Businesses. Canal locks attracted businesses to serve canal boat crews, locals, and farmers. Here at Lock 37 the Vanouceks ran a tavern and general store and the Alexander family operated a gristmill. A spillway allowed excess water to flow around the lock. The mill used the spillway’s waterpower to grind grain into flour and livestock feed.” The other wayside panel, titled “Floods and Repairs,” is down the path to the right as you face the lock. It sits on the other side of the path near the river which lies close to the canal at this point. Just past the panel is a wooden bridge without railings that crosses a small channel which carries water between the canal on the left and the river on the right. Four gear-like mechanisms line the right side of the bridge which control openings in a gate below. Text on the panel reads, “Regulating Water Level. Canal engineers did not foresee the intensity of valley floods and later added structures to control water levels. Here a National Park Service worker adjusts a floodgate built in the early 1900s. Look closely at the actual structure. Can you see the small gates below where the worker is standing? Gates are opened to drain off water so canal repairs can be made here or downstream. During floods, excess water is diverted to protect the canal from being damaged. A waste way takes the water to the Cuyahoga River.” The photograph on the panel shows a man in a National Park Service uniform using a long metal rod to turn one of the gear mechanisms. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Lock 37 stands beside the historic Wilson Feed Mill, one of the last mills still operating on the Ohio & Erie Canal. A nearby flood gate helps control the water level.

title: Lock 38 at Canal Exploration Center
listingDescription: What is a canal lock? Stop here to learn about the mechanics of these boat elevators. If you are lucky to have water in the canal on a summer weekend, you might see volunteers demonstrating how Lock 38 works.

images.altText: Four people in historic costume stand on the left side of a water-filled stone lock.
images.title: 20140514 CEC-L38 Grand Opening lock demo
images.caption: Lock demonstration in front of Canal Exploration Center.

bodyText: Outside of Canal Exploration Center is a reconstruction of Lock 38. On summer weekends when conditions allow, volunteers demonstrate how a lock operates. Canals were designed as waterways without waterfalls or a current. Locks were built to raise or lower canal boats wherever there was a significant change in elevation. A lock works much like a toy in a bathtub. If a boat needs to go up, water is let in through butterfly valves in the upstream gate. The chamber is filled until it is level with the upstream water. If the boat needs to go down, water is let out through butterfly valves in the downstream gate. When the water is low enough to match the downstream level, the downstream gates can be opened. To fit inside the locks on the Ohio & Erie Canal, boats could be no more than 75 feet long.
audioDescription: Lock 38. 470 words This wayside graphic panel sits at the downstream end of the lock. Behind the exhibit, a small wooden footbridge crosses to the other side. To the right of the bridge are the heavy wooden gates that close this end of the lock. Each gate has a long wooden beam attached along its top and extending out to the side. A similar pair of gates sit at the upper end of the lock to the right. On the other side of the towpath is a white-frame building that held a tavern and store. To the left of the lock is a road and bridge crossing the canal. That road ends at the scenic byway on the far side. The inside walls of the lock are made of concrete-covered stone blocks. The tops of the walls are even with the ground and there is no guardrail. At the left side of the panel, text reads, “Lock 38 is one of the few restored, working locks along the historic Ohio and Erie Canal. Locks are like elevators – they raise and lower boats between levels. State engineers designed 44 locks to deal with a 395-foot rise in elevation from Cleveland to Akron. Heavy wooden gates enclose the boat-sized stone chamber. Lock operators added water to the chamber to raise a boat headed upstream. They drained out water to lower a boat headed downstream.” The right side of the panel has a drawing of one of the wooden gates with its beam extending over the lock wall to the right, a man pushing on the end. Arrows indicate features of the diagram. The caption next to the end of the beam reads, “Balance beam. A long beam balances out each heavy gate. The beam makes it possible to open and close the gate by hand.” At the bottom of the gate is a small door called a wicket. The caption reads, “The gates cannot open unless the water level is the same on both sides. A valve at the bottom of each gate, called a wicket, lets water in or out.” At the top of the gate is a long shaft called a wicket stem connected to the wicket below. The caption reads, “Boatmen opened and closed the wicket using a large wrench to turn the wicket stem and pivot the wicket.” The gate itself is called a whaler gate. The caption reads, “Two gates at each end keep the water in the chamber.” At lower left is a photograph of the lock empty of water, showing the smooth vertical walls and a flooring made of wooden beams. The caption reads, “In the 1980s National Park Service workers restored Lock 38 to how it looked in 1907. This was just after the state lined locks with concrete. Notice the wooden floor.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Lock 38 is a reconstruction of the original lock outside what is now Canal Exploration Center. Also called Twelve Mile Lock, this is the last functioning lock that remains on the Ohio & Erie Canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places

title: Lock 39
listingDescription: Lock 39 is the northernmost lock in Cuyahoga Valley National Park. It is one of many canal remnants you can see as you walk, ride, or run along the Towpath Trail.

images.altText: Close up of an interpretive panel called Lock 39: Stepping Up and Down.
images.title: Lock 39 Photo
images.caption: The Lock 29 panel with a touchable profile of the locks between Akron and Cleveland.

bodyText:
In operation from 1827 to 1913, the Ohio & Erie Canal turned the sleepy village of Cleveland into a major port. Boats carried timber and farm products to Lake Erie and returned with manufactured goods and specialty foods.

Unlike Ohio’s rivers, canals offered a consistent depth for boats to travel and no current. Yet the land they travel through is not flat. Water is travelling north from a high point near Portage Lakes in Akron, down 395 feet to the level of Lake Erie at Cleveland. Whenever the drop of water or land was significant, a lock was installed to move boats up or down. In effect, locks acted as elevators for boats. Water would be let in from the higher side to raise the water level, or let out on the lower side to lower the boats.

Originally locks were made of carved sandstone, and often lined or “puddled” with clay to keep them from leaking. But water takes its toll. During 1905-1906 renovations, this sandstone lock was refaced with a new concrete surface, now also wearing away.

Along the Towpath Trail, a graphic panel describes the function of the locks. At the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile of the 44 stair-step locks between Akron and Cleveland.
audioDescription: Here on the canal is an old lock structure. At the side of the towpath near the lock a graphic panel describes the function of the locks. At the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile of the 44 stair-step locks between Lake Erie in Cleveland and the portage summit in Akron. To the right of the panel is a bench made of wooden beams between two concrete bases. Across the path from the canal is an overgrown field backed by woods.  The canal and lock contain water. The sides of the lock are made of stone and concrete. At the left, or northern end, a small footbridge crosses the lock to a grassy area on the other side. The end of the lock closest to the graphic panel is closed with a thick, wooden barrier keeping the water level feet below ground level. On the northern side of the barrier gate, the water is ten feet below the ground level. Exercise caution near the lock as there is no guardrail. Water trickles under the barrier to fall into the deep lock.  The background of the graphic shows a black and white photograph of a functional lock. The view up the lock shows the block walls and water splashing through the partially open, heavy wooden gate at the end. A note tells us that “Canal managers covered the blocks with concrete during a 1905-1906 renovation.” Along the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile with braille labels of the lock system. The edges of the profile can be sharp. Lake Erie at 573 feet is at the left end. Forty-four locks form stair steps up to 968-foot-high Portage Summit at the right end. In between are Boston at Lock 32, Peninsula at Lock 29, and Mustill Store at Lock 15. Text on the panel reads,   “Stepping Up and Down. Locks act like elevators, raising and lowering boats. Most locks along the Ohio and Erie Canal had a lift of about nine feet. It took 44 locks to manage the 395-foot elevation rise between Cleveland and Akron. Canal engineers numbered locks in both directions from Akron’s Portage Summit. In operation from 1827 to 1913, the canal turned the sleepy village of Cleveland into a major port. Boats carried timber and farm products to Lake Erie and returned with manufactured goods and specialty foods.”  End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Lock 39 Trailhead, 8000 Rockside Road, Independence, Ohio 44131 and hike south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ohio & Erie Canal was once a vital transportation route, connecting Ohio to growing East Coast cities such as New York. Engineers built locks such as this one to manage water flow and to raise and lower boats.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio & Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places

title: Lock 39 River Access
listingDescription: Access the river from the Lock 39 Trailhead in Valley View. This site allows access for a long paddle, nearly 12 miles, into Cleveland. Rockside Station and food are nearby.

images.altText: A lowered area along the Cuyahoga River used by paddlers to access the river.
images.title: Lock 39 River Access Point
images.caption: The Cuyahoga River at the Lock 39 access, showing the path to the trailhead parking lot.

bodyText:
This site allows access to a section of the Cuyahoga River Water Trail and provides for a long paddle, nearly 12 miles, into Cleveland. Rockside Station and food are nearby. A small pathway is located on the southwest side of the parking lot at the Lock 39 Trailhead just north (downstream) of the pedestrian bridge. The Lock 39 parking area is relatively small. If the parking lot is full, overflow parking is located at the Rockside Station parking area.

Things to Know for Paddlers:

  • Paved parking lot and hiking and biking trail at trailhead.
  • Restrooms, picnicking, and drinking water nearby at Rockside Station (follow connecting trail with pedestrian bridge).
  • Restaurants and restrooms at the shopping plaza across the street.
  • Dropoff/pickup 100 feet from water’s edge.
  • Boarding for shuttle option on Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad during Bike Aboard season. See Lock 29, Boston Store, and Station Road Bridge river access sites for details.
  • Takeout for pedal/paddle option. Use the Towpath Trail to bike/run/walk back to upstream access points as far as Lock 29 Trailhead.
  • Class I downstream paddle to Merwin’s Wharf enters the shipping channel for the last four miles. Proceed with caution.

Known Hazards:

Downstream:

  • Use extra caution in Cleveland. Huge freighters and motorized recreational boats share the shipping channel. Visit the Cuyahoga River Water Trail hazards page for more information about this section of the river.

Upstream:

  • Before Lock 39 Trailhead, tall metal pylons in the river can create log jams. Portage right if needed. Know the river flow before you go. Check river gauges.
audioDescription: Lock 39 River Access. 200 words Lock 39 River Access. 200 words The Cuyahoga River Water Trail access at Lock 39 is located on the east bank of the river. The path to the river access starts at Lock 39 Trailhead, in the southwest corner of the parking lot. The path to the access point is north of the pedestrian bridge to Rockside Station. It is a dirt trail through the woods with tree branches along the path. The path slopes downward as you approach the river. When you reach the access point, the river will be in front of you. The ground flattens out as you reach the river. The ground has loose rock and dirt that leads into the water. The flat area extends left and ends just below the pedestrian bridge, left. The pedestrian bridge extends over the river connecting Lock 39 and Rockside Station. To the left and behind you is a dark blue sign that has the Cuyahoga River Water Trail logo with “Lock 39 Rockside Road.” Underneath the text on the sign is a lighter blue shaded area with the number “13.2.” To the right the Rockside Road is visible. The terrain is uneven and has trees and sticks throughout. End of description. When you reach the access point, the river will be in front of you. The ground flattens out as you reach the river. The ground has loose rock and dirt that leads into the water. The flat area extends left and ends just below the pedestrian bridge, left. The pedestrian bridge extends over the river connecting Lock 39 and Rockside Station. To the left and behind you is a dark blue sign that has the Cuyahoga River Water Trail logo with “Lock 39 Rockside Road.” Underneath the text on the sign is a lighter blue shaded area with the number “13.2.” To the right the Rockside Road is visible. The terrain is uneven and has trees and sticks throughout. End of description.
