title: Lock 39 Trailhead Information
listingDescription: This is the northernmost trailhead within Cuyahoga Valley. From here, visitors can explore the Towpath Trail south into the national park or north into Cleveland Metroparks. Across the parking lot is an access point for the Cuyahoga River Water Trail and a pedestrian bridge to Rockside Station.

images.altText: A three-sided kiosk and bench are at a fork. The trail on the right is beside a water-filled canal.
images.title: Parking Lot From Towpath at Lock 39
images.caption: This information kiosk is along the Towpath Trail, downhill from the Lock 39 Trailhead parking lot.

bodyText:
Nearby Lock 39 is one of over 200 locks that once operated along the Ohio & Erie Canal. With its heyday in the mid-1800s, the canal was part of the early transportation system in the young United States. People and goods were flowing between East Coast cities and the rural heartland, pushing America’s borders westward.

Today this area is a hub of recreational activity. Over a century ago, residents of greater Cleveland began looking for relaxation and recreation outside of crowded cities. Excursion canal boats, trains, and even horse drawn carriages brought visitors into the Cuyahoga Valley. You can now explore the Ohio & Erie Canal via the adjacent Towpath Trail by bike or by foot. You can see the valley too from the windows of the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad. Across the parking lot is a bridge to Rockside Station and an access down to the Cuyahoga River Water Trail. Visit this information kiosk to get oriented and pick your adventure.
audioDescription: Lock 39 Trailhead. 470 words A three-sided, covered kiosk sits at the side of the smooth, unpaved Towpath Trail next to a small bench. One side has a bulletin board with current news, while the other two sides have graphic panels. On the other side of the path is the canal, water at its bottom and a steep, brush-covered bank on the other side. A wooden post next to the canal has a small sign that reads “Lock 39, Towpath Trail.” Going left on the path leads to Cleveland Metroparks. Going right leads to the Canal Exploration Center. Trees and bushes line the side of the path opposite the canal. One of the graphic panels is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location at the northern end of the park marked. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Lock 39 Trailhead. The Rockside name probably comes from the many small quarries that once dotted this area. Travel by foot, bicycle, or rail to learn about Ohio’s transportation history. Canal Exploration Center is 1.75 miles south on the Towpath Trail. The CanalWay Center of Cleveland Metroparks is about four miles north. From the nearby trailhead parking lot, cross the footbridge to reach Rockside Station. This is the northern starting point for the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad.” The third side has a panel titled “Ohio and Erie Canalway” with a large black and white photograph of three mules pulling a canal boat on the canal. Smaller photographs show the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad, a group of children riding bicycles on the towpath and the scenic byway that winds through the valley. A long map down the right side shows mileage between trailheads on the Towpath Trail. Text on the panel reads, “The Ohio and Erie Canalway celebrates the first 110 miles of a waterway that helped the nation grow. Dug by hand from 1825 to 1832, the Ohio and Erie Canal was the first canal west of the Appalachian Mountains. It connected Lake Erie to the Ohio River, providing a key link in an interstate shipping route. People and products flowed across America. Canal towns became major commercial centers. Ohio grew in population and wealth. Today you can explore the lasting impact of this historic public works project. Travel along the Canalway’s three spines. Discover how culture, recreation, and natural scenic beauty are being revitalized by this national heritage area.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: 8000 Rockside Road, Independence, Ohio 44131
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: This is a gateway to Cuyahoga Valley National Park to the south and Cleveland Metroparks to the north. Nearby Lock 39 is a remnant of the historic Ohio & Erie Canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Moody and Thomas Mill Site
listingDescription: Falling water once provided power to grind grain into flour. Hermon Bronson built a grist mill here in 1832, conveniently located on the new Ohio & Erie Canal. Today the mill race and crumbling foundation are all that remain.

images.altText: A trail leads by a graphic panel and stone wall, and crosses a pedestrian bridge to a parking lot.
images.title: Moody and Thomas Mill Site Panel
images.caption: The mill foundation and exhibit are across the Cuyahoga River from Lock 29.

bodyText:
Peninsula founder Hermon Bronson knew how to take advantage of a natural fall in the Cuyahoga River. In 1832, he built a water-powered grist mill here, beside the Ohio & Erie Canal. Local farmers came to the mill to have their grain ground and then shipped out to distant markets on canal boats. When the Valley Railway arrived in 1880, it competed with the canal. To get goods over the river to the new station, the mill built a bridge from its upper level to the east bank. Wagons heavy with ground grain and feed crossed over and were offloaded onto freight cars.

In 1902, Chandler Moody and Charles Thomas bought the mill and enlarged it. They continued to mill flour and feed until 1931, when a fire burned the mill to the ground. While the dust from grinding grain is highly combustible, questions have remained about the fire.

For more history, head north to Lock 29 or head south to Deep Lock Quarry. For your safety and to protect park resources, do not climb on the stone ruins.
audioDescription: Moody and Thomas Mill Site. 277 words This wayside graphic panel is on the left side of the Towpath Trail as you cross the bridge over the Cuyahoga River. As you face the panel, the river makes a bend in front of you, turning to pass to your left then bending away from you to continue north. To the right is a backless bench alongside the towpath which continues to the south. On the other side of the path, directly behind you, are the remains of the aqueduct, which carried the canal over the river. All that is left are partial walls made of sandstone blocks. In front of you between the panel and the river are ruined walls from the old gristmill, half buried by trees and other vegetation. Text on the panel reads, “Gristmill, Reaching Distant Markets. In 1832 Hermon Bronson built a gristmill here to grind wheat into flour. He shipped the flour to market on the Ohio and Erie Canal. After the Valley Railway arrived, the mill built a bridge over the river. Wagons carried grain from the train and returned with loads of flour and livestock feed. Chandler Moody and Charles Thomas bought and enlarged the mill in 1902.” The panel is filled with a color-tinted photograph of the mill taken from the south, right of your current position. The large white frame building has three floors with an even taller section on the right topped by a cupola. The canal runs from the foreground past the mill on the left. A caption reads, “A fire destroyed the Moody and Thomas Mill in 1931. Fine dust from grain processing is highly combustible.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Lock 29 Trailhead, 1648 Mill Street, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Take the Towpath Trail south across the river.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: This mill was busy grinding for almost a century. It was a testament to the farmers shipping out grain first on the Ohio & Erie Canal and later on the Valley Railway.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Peninsula Village Historic District; Ohio to Erie Trail; Ohio & Erie Canalway National Heritage Area; Ohio and Erie Canal District
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Mudcatcher
listingDescription: Across the canal here, visitors can see the manmade Mudcatcher Falls. The stone abutment was built to hold back soil and debris from entering the canal. From this vantage point, visitors can travel north or south on the Towpath. To the north, in less than a tenth of a mile, the Valley horse trail will veer off to the left. In early spring, visitors may be lucky enough to see a bald eagle from this trail.

images.altText: In a half circle bump out, a square graphic panel overlooks a canal choked with soil. On the opposit
images.title: Mudcatcher
images.caption: Here Gaulley Run, an intermittent stream, flows over the stone Mudcatcher and into the canal.

bodyText:
Maintaining a constant four feet of water in the Ohio & Erie Canal was a challenge. From the beginning, engineers struggled with too much or too little water. They built aqueducts and culverts where large streams crossed the manmade waterway. Some smaller, seasonal streams such as Gaulley Run were allowed to feed into the canal, replacing water lost to leaks and evaporation. Once farmers cleared trees from uplands fields and hillsides, erosion became a problem. Each year, maintenance crews used to dredge the canal to remove sediment swept in by storm water. This mudcatcher “caught” soil and debris floating in Gaulley Run and held it in a basin behind the wall. Since canal operations stopped, this basin has filled in. After heavy rains, mud and gravel flow over the opening and into the canal. Periodically, the National Park Service must dredge this section of canal. Look for accumulation under “Mudcatcher Falls.” This manmade waterfall flows during all but dry weather. A graphic panel explains the scene. 
 

From here, visitors can travel north or south on the Towpath Trail. To the north, in less than a tenth of a mile, the Valley Trail veers off to the left. A half mile to the south, there are more engineering stories to explore, as well as restrooms, in the Station Road Bridge area.
audioDescription: Mudcatcher. 241 words The towpath here winds between the canal and the river with woods on either side. On the canal side is a graphic wayside panel titled “Mudcatcher, Filtering the Flow.” On the far side of the canal, a stream runs down between two steep slopes towards the canal and river. Between the slopes is a dam-like structure made of large stone blocks. An opening in the middle allows the water to fall in a short waterfall into a pool below when the stream is running. Text on the panel reads, “Soil washing into the canal created an ongoing problem. Storms eroded upland fields and hillsides left treeless by farmers. Engineers usually built culverts under the canal to carry streams into the Cuyahoga River. Here the intermittent Galley Run flows directly into the canal. A mudcatcher – the stone structure in front of you – held back the soil in a basin. Crews dug out the mud and debris during the dry season. “With its basin full of muck, the mudcatcher no longer functions. Do you see sediment building up in the canal today? The National Park Service periodically needs to dredge this watered section.” The panel has a photograph of the scene in front of you with the parts labeled. Arrows indicate the steep sides of the ravine cut by the stream, the historic dam-like mudcatcher structure itself, and a pile of dirt and gravel between the mudcatcher and the canal. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Cross the bridge and walk north on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The mudcatcher may be the only structure of its kind left along the Ohio & Erie Canal. It is an example of the engineering needed to maintain a constant level of water in the canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Mule Power Panel and Statue
listingDescription: We can easily forget that America was once powered by animals, not by machines. Explore why mules were the preferred animal for pulling boats along the canal, as you meet “Blossom” the bronze mule.

images.altText: Life-sized mule statue and exhibit with tactile bronze mule; paved trail leads to a white building.
images.title: Mule Power Panel and Statue
images.caption: Blossom, the bronze mule, gazes at Canal Exploration Center.

bodyText:
When the Ohio & Erie Canal was first built, horses were commonly used to pull passenger packets. Horses required a lot of grain and can be overworked. Slower and steadier mules soon replaced them as the engine of choice. Mules are a cross between a horse and a donkey. This hybrid animal is smarter and more efficient than a horse. To pull 30 tons of freight required sturdy harnessing.

Today, a bronze statue of a mule in harness watches over the canal, commemorating the hundreds that once labored along the towpath. There is a graphic panel beside the statue with a tactile scale model.
audioDescription: Mule Power. 430 words At the side of the wide towpath is a free-standing graphic panel with a touchable model of a mule. Five feet to the right of the graphic is a life-size model of a mule which is also touchable. As you face the graphic, the canal is behind you, water in its bottom. Down the path to the right is the Canal Exploration Center and a working lock. Text on the panel reads, “Towing Canal Boats. Hi, I’m Blossom. During the canal days, mules like me walked the towpath, pulling heavy boats behind us. We were strong engines, able to haul 60 tons or more of freight. Mules worked in teams of two or three. Cargo boats had a middle cabin to stable a second team. The two teams switched every six hours. “Some people say mules are stubborn, but I think we’re just smart. Horses can work themselves to an early grave. Mules have enough sense to stop when we’re tired. And we refuse to do anything dangerous. Over time horses will get mouth and harness sores. Not mules. We are also cheaper to feed. Now I’m not saying horses are bad. They are faster than mules. Early passenger boats used teams of horses when speed was more important than endurance. I got my intelligence from my father. He’s a donkey. I got my athletic ability from my mother. She’s a horse. What is the best trait that you inherited from each parent?” At bottom left of the panel is a black and white photograph of boy leading a team down a towpath. The caption reads, “After the Civil War, canal boats became family businesses. One of the captain’s children was often the muleskinner, leading the team along the towpath. Horses, like the ones in this photo, weren’t as strong as mules.” At upper right is a color photograph of a two-mule team hauling a boat. The caption reads, “Mules pull a boat on the Miami and Erie Canal near Toledo, Ohio. Notice the long tow rope and how the team is hitched nose-to-tail.” To explore the small touchable mule model, start at the head at the left. Notice the long ears and, moving down the neck, the short mane. The neck collar of the harness has two prongs at the top. Move back along the body to feel the strap around its girth and leading backward. At the mule’s rear, notice the tail is wrapped along half its length. The life-size model to the right is the same, although it is facing the other direction. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Mules were once the dominant “horse” power of the canal, yet today few people even know what one looks like. This bronze mule celebrates the many mules that once pulled boats along the canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Oak Hill Trailhead
listingDescription: The Oak Hill area is a favored area for birding, running, hiking, fishing, photography, and cross country skiing. Once farmed, the area is now returning to forest. Two trails intertwine here – the shorter 1.8-mile Oak Hill and the longer 5-mile Plateau trail. They skirt farm ponds and deep ravines.

images.altText: “Oak Hill” kiosk stands between a wooden bench and a two door restroom with trees in the background.
images.title: Oak Hill Trailhead Information
images.caption: The loop trail network starts and ends on either side of the bulletin board and restroom area.

bodyText:
Like other areas in the park, the Oak Hill area was once farmland. Today it is one of the largest roadless tracts in the national park. As you hike along the trails here, look for clues to the former farm fields, with fencerow edges, old farm lanes, and planted trees.

Farmers had built ponds and cleared fields. Today those cleared fields have reverted to meadows. The ponds remain today, and attract wildlife and anglers. Wildness is slowly returning to the area.

Two trails intertwine here, the shorter 1.8-mile Oak Hill Trail and the longer 5-mile Plateau Trail. They are popular for hiking, running, cross country skiing, and snow shoeing. The longer trail declines down to the valley floor, which means a hill back up to the parking lot level. The Cuyahoga Valley Environmental Education Center is near here; please respect trail closures to this area. Do be aware, trails can become muddy during spring or times of rain.
audioDescription: Oak Hill Trailhead. 251 words. At the side of this unpaved parking lot is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. As you face the kiosk, a small building with men’s and women’s toilets lies just beyond it on the right side. A bench sits in the grass to the left of the kiosk. The trail makes a loop and may be accessed on either side of the kiosk. The area surrounding the parking lot is a mix of old fields and patches of woods. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location a bit south of the middle of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Oak Hill Trailhead. The Oak Hill area is one of the largest roadless tracts in Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Forest is slowly replacing the earlier farm fields and lanes. Several meadows and constructed ponds dot the area, attracting wildlife and anglers alike. Whether you come with a fishing, a camera, cross-country skis, or binoculars, enjoy the area’s renewed wildness.” End of description.

title: Octagon Shelter and Exhibits
listingDescription: The Octagon Shelter is a great example of a style of architecture that came to be known as “parkitecture.” This type of architecture fit well into the natural landscape. It became synonymous with Civilian Conservation Corps structures. Groups and families with up to 50 people may reserve it for a fee.

images.altText: Brown wooden building with 3 stone chimneys and an octagonal main section lined with small windows.
images.title: Octagon Shelter and Panel
images.caption: Octagon is a reservable picnic shelter with public restrooms.

bodyText:
The National Park Service provided the planners and the Civilian Conservation Corps provided the labor to construct Octagon Shelter. The building’s architecture is affectionately known as “parkitecture.” The Civilian Conservation Corps commonly used this style in parks around the country.

Parkitecture is reminiscent of the craftsmanship of early carpenters. It includes the use of heavy beams, low silhouettes, horizontal lines, and colors and materials found in local surroundings. The Octagon shape here was more complicated, yet it still looks like a natural, almost native part of the landscape. A large grassy playfield sits next to and in harmony with the shelter.

Today, the Octagon Shelter may be reserved at recreation.gov by groups and families with up to 50 people for a fee. The shelter is an eight-sided pavilion with seven picnic tables, two fireplaces, and an outdoor grill. It is enclosed from October 15 – May 14 and open-sided the rest of the year. Electrical outlets for normal, two-pronged household appliances such as coffee pots and crock pots are available. It does not have centralized heat. Drinking water is available at a fountain from May 1 to September 15. Restrooms with flush toilets are available year-round.
audioDescription: Octagon Shelter. 436 words This wayside graphic panel faces this dark brown, wooden structure. At right the building is shaped like an 8-sided octagon. One of two wide stone fireplace chimneys is on the side closest to us. At left, a wing extends out to the side. During the warmer months, several side panels are removed. Inside the floor is paved with flagstones and picnic tables are arranged around the walls. In the center is a central column surround by a built-in bench. On the far side of the left wing is a patio area with more picnic tables and access to the restrooms. A wide grassy lawn extends around the left side bordered by trees. Text on the wayside panel reads, “Parkitecture. The Octagon Shelter, like most Civilian Conservation Corps structures, used ‘rustic style’ architecture developed in the early 1900s by National Park Service planners. Coined ‘parkitecture,’ rustic style emphasizes low silhouettes, horizontal lines, and colors and materials found in local surroundings. The octagon shape is reminiscent of shelters found in the Adirondack Mountains, which provide sweeping views of the surrounding area.” The bottom of the panel has an architect’s drawing of this side of the building showing the octagon-shaped pavilion at right and the wing extending to the left. At left a quote reads, “The use of native materials in proper scale, and the thorough avoidance of rigid, straight lines, and over sophistication, gives the feeling of having been executed by pioneer craftsmen with limited hand tools. It achieves sympathy with natural surroundings and with the past. – A.H. Good, Akron architect and designer of Virginia Kendall facilities, defining rustic architecture.” On a wall inside the shelter is a graphic panel titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” which features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the eastern side of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. Octagon Shelter. Coal industrialist Hayward Kendall willed his private retreat, later named Virginia Kendall Park, to the people of Ohio following his death in 1927. Managed by different agencies over the years, the park gave area residents more space for recreation and play. Most of the Virginia Kendall structures were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s.” End of description.

title: Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area
listingDescription: The Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area spurred economic development across the nation by creating an inland connection for goods from Lake Erie to the Ohio River, known as the heartland of America to the eastern seaboard. This development fueled westward expansion, a national market economy, a booming industrial manufacturing sector, and the settlement of towns, villages, and cities along the canal.

images.credit: Photo Courtesy of Tim Fitzwater, Canalway Partners, and the Ohio and Erie Canalway Coalition
images.altText: Bikers and cattleman enjoy a trail
images.title: Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage
images.caption: The city of Canal Fulton offers different ways to experience and enjoy the Canalway.

bodyText:
The Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area was designated by Congress in 1996 to preserve and celebrate the culture, history, and heritage of this resource which changed the nation. The Canalway Partners and the Ohio & Erie Canalway Coalition both serve as the coordinating entity for the heritage area.  

When the Ohio and Erie Canal was built between 1825 and 1832, there were only 22 states at the time. Nineteenth-century Ohio was geographically isolated from the economic prosperity of the east by the Appalachian Mountains. A lack of transit routes made obtaining and exporting goods and services difficult. Upon its completion in 1832, the Canal connected Lake Erie and the Ohio River to the Erie Canal, creating a vital transportation route between the East Coast and the Gulf of Mexico, allowing resources to flow more freely across Ohio and the nation. It is known for providing “routes of prosperity.”  

The creation of this inland water transportation system was a key point in the nation’s journey to becoming self-reliant on resource development, rather than relying on European trade routes. The Ohio & Erie Canal attracted pioneers, immigrants, and entrepreneurs to the region, leading to interconnected and thriving communities blossoming with opportunity for new business and industry. As the rise of railroads led to decreased use of the canal for transportation, industrial development continued on the canal's banks to harness its hydroelectric power.  

In March of 1913, Ohio experienced a great flood, considered to be the second deadliest flood in the United States and the most devastating natural disaster Ohio ever experienced. The Ohio and Erie Canal was damaged beyond repair and ultimately abandoned. While this hurt local communities, their tenacity was unwavering. Community members knew the vitality of this region would be long-lasting if they worked to connect people back to their shared history of the Canalway. Today, the canal is still used for transportation, but this time for hiking, running, and cycling along the Towpath Trail, a recreation path that follows the old Canalway route and continues to connect the region's communities.  

Historic Sites and Points of Interest: 

  1. Towpath Trail and Greenway   

  1. Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad 

  1. National Scenic Byway 

  1. Western Reserve Historical Society 

  1. Ohio & Erie Canal Reservation 

  1. Industrial Valley & Cuyahoga River

  1. Richard Howe House  

  1. Congressman Ralph Regula Canalway Center 

  1. Canal Fulton 

  1. Historic Zoar Village 

Notable People: 

  1. Simon Perkins 

  1. John D. Rockefeller 

  1. Alfred Kelley 

  1. John Malvin
managedByOrg: Canalway Partners and Ohio & Erie Canalway Coalition

title: Ohio's Lake Placid Panel
listingDescription: The Civilian Conservation Corps built many outdoor recreation amenities, including toboggan chutes. Here an exhibit examines the last chutes that once stood here, providing winter fun for some 40 years.

images.altText: Exhibit stands beside a dirt trail, right, leading into a tunnel under a tree-covered slope.
images.title: Ohio's Lake Placid Panel
images.caption: A graphic panel on the Lake Trail marks the wooded slope where toboggans once ran.

bodyText: The Civilian Conservation Corps built amenities that supported year-round enjoyment of Kendall Lake for outdoor recreation. Ice skating and toboggan chutes provided winter fun. A slope leading to Kendall Lake is a remnant of the most recent toboggan run, built in 1939. Many of the large evergreens lining the slope were planted around the same time to provide shelter and shade for the iced toboggan runs. The tunnel allowed visitors to hike the foot trail without having to cross the toboggan slide.
audioDescription: Ohio’s Lake Placid. 288 words This wayside graphic panel sits at the side of an unpaved path that leads down a wooded slope. As you face the panel, the path to the right leads up the slope and through a short tunnel at the top. In the other direction the path continues downhill. Directly behind you, on the other side of the path, the ground slopes away steeply. Text at the top of the panel reads, “While many Civilian Conservation Corps, or CCC, crews worked on projects involving flood control and soil erosion, Company 576 focused on building recreational facilities at Virginia Kendall Park. Projects were diverse and included: a lake for fishing, swimming, and skating; hiking trails; picnic shelters; and even toboggan chutes. The slope in front of you is a remnant of the most recent toboggan run, built in 1939. Many of the large evergreens lining the slope were planted at the same time to provide shelter and shade for the iced toboggan runs. The tunnel to your right was constructed to allow visitors to hike the foot trail without having to cross the toboggan slide.’ At bottom left is a photograph of four people, broad smiles on their faces, seated on a toboggan with a curved-up front sliding down an icy trough through the woods, snow covering the ground. The caption reads, “First opened in 1936, the Virginia Kendall toboggan chutes served winter enthusiasts for more than 40 years before being removed in 1990.” At right is a smaller photograph taken from the surface of the lake showing two chutes side by side down a grassy hill. The caption reads, “CCC projects like the toboggan chutes helped promote year-round recreation in the 1930s and 1940s.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Kendall Lake Trailhead, 1000 Truxell Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Hike the Lake Trail clockwise, just after the tunnel.

title: Old Canal Bed Panel
listingDescription: Pause on this footbridge to gaze into the bed of the historic Ohio & Erie Canal. Nature is reclaiming this built waterway. Observe how a seasonal stream is carving its way down the valley walls to the Cuyahoga River. From here, continue on the flat Towpath Trail or head uphill to the Old Carriage Trail and the Bike & Hike Trail.

images.altText: An angled view of a wooden bridge with a bench and exhibit panel, over a dry, woodland streambed.
images.title: Old Canal Bed Panel and Footbridge
images.caption: Step onto the footbridge to see how natural forces and people have shaped this view.

bodyText:
Pause here to ponder how nature’s return is changing Cuyahoga Valley. From this footbridge, look out over the remains of the Ohio & Erie Canal. Notice how a stream cuts across the old canal bed, seeking the Cuyahoga River. Where mules once pulled heavily laden boats, trees now drop their loads of leaves into the water. This provides shade, food, and shelter to salamanders and other small aquatic creatures. Park scientists look for pollution-sensitive wildlife as a sign of environmental health. Protecting small, free-flowing streams is important to the river’s recover. The National Park Service maintains the canal as a ruin, a testament to nature’s ability to forgive and recover.

If you cross the footbridge and head uphill, the 1.5-mile connector leads to the Old Carriage Trail and the Bike and Hike Trail. Continuing on the Towpath Trail takes you north to Station Road Bridge Trailhead or south to Red Lock Trailhead.
audioDescription: Old Canal Bed. 386 words This wayside graphic panel sits on a wooden footbridge across the mostly dry canal bed, connecting the Towpath Trail with a hiking path through the woods to the east of the canal. There is a bench on the bridge to the right of the panel. The stream bed below may or may not have water, depending on the season and recent rainfall. The right side of the panel has a color illustration looking down the canal bed, towpath to the left. The back of the drawing shows the view as it would have been when the canal was in use, a boat floating on water in the canal with a team of mules on the towpath. The front part of the drawing shows the scene as the canal returns to nature, with vegetation growing in the dry canal bed and animals – a racoon and two deer – on the right. Text at the left reads, “Letting Nature Take its Course. Nature has been reclaiming the Ohio and Erie Canal since the Great Flood of 1913 ended operations of this artificial waterway. The national park maintains a watered section north of Station Road Bridge but otherwise manages the canal as a ruin. A more natural flow of water allows habitats to recover. “Look around. A headwater stream meanders down the valley wall behind you and across the canal bed. Shade trees and shrubs are returning, keeping the water cool to support more aquatic life. Leaves fall among the wet rocks and break down into food for small bottom-dwelling animals. Small streams like this one drain into the Cuyahoga River and are vital to its health.” At bottom left is a photograph of a woman in park uniform kneeling beside a small stream. She looks down at a small salamander in her palm. The caption reads, “Scientists look for salamanders and aquatic insects as living indicators of clean water. Cobblestones clean of silt are another sign.” At top right is an image of a salamander, looking similar to a lizard but without scaly skin. An inset photo shows a stonefly nymph (a long, thin insect with a yellow and black striped body and forked tail) floating underwater. The caption reads, “Northern dusky salamanders and some aquatic insects they eat are very sensitive to pollution.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Red Lock Trailhead, 1175 Highland Road, Sagamore Hills, Ohio 44067. Walk north on the Towpath Trail to the first footbridge.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ohio & Erie Canal was once a vital transportation route, connecting Ohio and lands to the west to a growing eastern population. The canal is now maintained as a ruin. Here a small headwater stream winds across the old waterway to the Cuyahoga River. Healthy streams nourish the river’s recovery.

title: Peninsula Depot
listingDescription: The Peninsula Depot is an original station from the historic Valley Railway. Today it serves as a ticketing office and boarding location for the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad.

images.altText: A red building with white trim. Depot has a platform, ramp, posted train schedule, and bay window.
images.title: Peninsula Depot CVSR
images.caption: Peninsula Depot is painted red, while the stations built by NPS are yellow.

bodyText:
Peninsula Depot is a ticketing office and boarding location for Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad. It is also the only historic depot remaining in the valley. However, even it has gone through change.

When the Valley Railway opened in 1880, every community along its route through the Cuyahoga Valley had a depot. A fire destroyed the original Peninsula Depot in the 1960s. In 1968, local designer and historic preservationist Robert Hunker purchased the depot in the village of Boston and moved it two miles to this location. Thus, today’s Peninsula Depot started its life as the Boston Mill Depot.

The Peninsula Depot is a typical combination station that served passengers and freight. Railroads were among the first companies to standardize business practices, including building architecture. A station agent operated the depot from the middle office, selling tickets, planning travel itineraries, and reporting freight and express movements.

Shops, restaurants, and trails are a short walk from the depot. To reach restrooms and the Towpath Trail, cross the tracks at the designated crossing and walk the path along the river to the right. Follow the blue blazes to the east and up an old road to access the Valley and Buckeye trails. The Cuyahoga River Water Trail has an access point in the Lock 29 area.
audioDescription: Peninsula Depot. 271 words The train station is a red building with white trim and a red roof. Four steps with handrails on either side lead up to the main platform. The platform has a red door straight ahead with a wall mounted sign to the right. It reads “Peninsula Depot” and has sections for train, arriving, departing, from, to, and remarks. To the right is a red bench on the edge of the platform. To the left of the door is a bay window. A sign with the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad winged logo hangs from the center section. Directly behind you are the train tracks. A paved path over the tracks connects to a path on the other side. To the right of the main steps is a ramp with rails on both sides that leads to the back of the depot. Behind the depot to the right is the Trail Mix Peninsula store. There are several picnic tables, one wheelchair accessible, in the paved area out front. A black floor mat leads from the foot of the step to the picnic area. A paved trail runs parallel to the tracks, leading past Trail Mix to a parking lot for a local restaurant. Across the tracks to the right is the parking area for Century Cycles. To the left of the main steps, beside the depot, is an open shelter with white posts and a red roof. It has seating to wait for the train. Down the path on the other side of the tracks is a red building with a black roof. It is an accessible public restroom. End of description.

quickFacts.value: 1630 Mill Street, Peninsula, Ohio 44264 with nearby parking at Lock 29 Trailhead.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Painted a characteristic red, Peninsula Depot is the only original train station remaining in the Cuyahoga Valley. At one time, thousands of these standardized, small depots could be found throughout the United States.

title: Pilgerruh Panel
listingDescription: Pilgerruh means “pilgrim’s rest.” From 1786-87, Christian Lenape and Moravian missionaries sought refuge near Tinkers Creek.

images.altText: Graphic panel with two illustrations—of a village and of a massacre—and a painting of red-headed man
images.title: Pilgerruh Panel Photo
images.caption: Somewhere near this panel, Christian Lenape and Moravian missionaries overwintered fleeing violence.

bodyText:
Shortly after the American Revolution, 95 Christian Lenape and six Moravian-German missionaries built a temporary village near the mouth of Tinkers Creek. Despite a good description from a diary, the exact location of Pilgerruh, or Pilgrim’s Rest, is unknown. The group was hungry and terrified, displaced during the years following the Gnaddenhutten massacre. As pacifists, they were distrusted by the British, the Americans, and other Native American groups. They took refuge in Cuyahoga Valley for ten months in 1786-1787, overwintering and raising crops before moving on.

The community found a permanent home along the Thames River in southern Ontario in 1792. Their descendants are among the Delaware Nation of Moraviantown.
audioDescription: Pilgerruh. 273 words At the side of the towpath is a free-standing graphic panel, facing an over-grown field surrounded by trees. As you face the panel, the canal is behind you. On the far side of the canal the scenic byway parallels the canal. The background of the panel features an artist’s sketch of a settlement of small, rectangular log buildings. Text on the panel reads, “Escaping Conflict. Fleeing intolerance, 95 Christian Lenape and six Moravian-German missionaries spent ten months nearby in 1786-87. Their temporary village was later called Pilgerruh, or Pilgrim’s Rest. After a harvest of corn and other vegetables, the group overwintered and then continued on. When the American Revolution began, all sides distrusted these pacifists. Traditional American Indian were suspicious of their Anglo ways. The British had removed the group from the Gnadenhutten settlement in Tuscarawas County south of here. In the following year, 1782, some returned to harvest corn, and were massacred by a Pennsylvania militia. Pause to consider how the Cuyahoga Valley was a short-lived refuge during violent times.” To the right of the text is a small portrait of Pilgerruh missionary David Zeisberger, dressed in a plain brown jacket with his wavy brown hair reaching below his collar. In the upper right is a drawing of several men dressed in fringed leather clothing standing over a pile of bodies as they attack with guns, knives and clubs. The caption reads, “In 1782 Pennsylvania militia attacked Christian Lenape at the Moravian Mission in Gnadenhutten, Ohio. They massacred over 90, a third of whom were children. Among the few young survivors, Jacob and Thomas rejoined David Zeisberger and others.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125 and hike north on the Towpath Trail

title: Pine Grove Trailhead Information
listingDescription: Access two of the interconnected trails in Virginia Kendall Park from the Pine Grove Trailhead. The 1.8-mile Ledges Trail circles around a sandstone outcrop with towering cliffs. The 2.2-mile Pine Grove Trail wanders through areas with planted pine trees and along the edge of wooded ravines. Both trails are relatively flat with uneven surfaces.

images.altText: Brown “Octagon” bulletin board with roof and 3 map boxes. Unpaved trail leads right into the woods.
images.title: Pine Grove Trailhead Kiosk
images.caption: The Pine Grove Trail begins at the top of the Octagon parking lot.

bodyText:
The Pine Grove Trailhead is a junction point in Virginia Kendall Park’s interconnected trail system. Here you can access the 1.8-mile Ledges Trail, which loops around a towering sandstone outcropping. You can also access the Pine Grove Trail, named after the number of planted pine trees further along the 2.2-mile trail.

The paths to the left and behind the kiosk both lead to the Ledges Trail. Take the left route to access a connector trail to the Ledges Shelter. Take the path behind the kiosk to head towards the Ledges Overlook, which is 0.5 miles down the Ledges Trail. The trail to your right will take you to the Pine Grove Trail.

The area around you was once part of the industrialist Hayward Kendall’s private retreat. He willed it to the state of Ohio as a park to be named after his mother, Virginia Kendall. The Civilian Conservation Corps developed the area’s amenities in the 1930s. Today people still use the Virginia Kendall area to recreate, play, and relax. What will you discover?

Learn more about the geology of the Cuyahoga Valley.
audioDescription: Pine Grove Trailhead. 247 words Here at the corner of the parking lot is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. Three unpaved trails through the woods meet here. As you face the kiosk, the trails to the left and behind the kiosk both lead to the Ledges Trail, a 1.8-mile loop. On the right is the Pine Grove Trail, a 2.2-mile trail that provides a relatively flat walk through areas with planted pine trees along the edge of wooded ravines. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the eastern side of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place of retreat from urban life. Building on this tradition, citizens worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked Earth Day and the Clean Water Act. “Pine Grove Trailhead. Coal industrialist Hayward Kendall willed his private retreat, later named Virginia Kendall Park, to the people of Ohio following his death in 1927. Managed by different agencies over the years, the park gave Akron and Cleveland more space for recreation and play. Most of the Virginia Kendall structures were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s.” End of description.

title: Pine Hollow Trailhead Information
listingDescription: The Pine Hollow Trailhead, with its plentiful parking, sits at the top of the Kendall Hills. The location offers scenic views, a popular sledding destination, and year-round trail access. From here you can access the Salt Run or Wetmore trails, or follow connectors to the Lake and Cross Country trails.

images.altText: Brown bulletin board with roof and map boxes by a paved trail. Brown fence and picnic table behind.
images.title: Pine Hollow Trailhead Kiosk
images.caption: Pine Hollow provides access to the Kendall Hills, popular for winter sledding and year-round hikes.

bodyText:
The Pine Hollow Trailhead is a large parking area and outdoor recreation hub that sits at the top of the Kendall Hills. It is a place where you can set your own pace. Race down the hills on a sled on a snowy day. Slow down to enjoy the scenery and nearby trails.

In the 1800s, the Ritchie family farmed this area. As Cleveland and Akron became major industrial cities after the Civil War, business leaders began buying farmland for valley retreats. Cleveland industrialist Hayward Kendall purchased much of the area. He willed his property to the state for a park and asked that it be named for his mother, Virginia Kendall.

Kendall Hills was not part of the original Virginia Kendall Park. In 1936 the Akron Metropolitan Park District wrote to neighbor A.A. Stambaugh, vice-president of Standard Oil, offering to lease the property. Winter sports enthusiasts were spilling over from the Kendall Lake area for coasting and skiing whenever the toboggan chutes were crowded. Stambaugh said that wasn’t necessary, he was happy to see the land used.

Today, the scenery is dominated by oak, hickory, and beech woodlands that have reclaimed the former farmland surrounding the hills. Dark green of stands of white and red pines dot the woodlands. They were planted by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s to hurry forest regeneration. The hills themselves are a mix of mowed grass and meadow. In late summer, meadow flowers attract butterflies and other pollinators.

Pine Hollow provides access to the park’s interconnected trail system. The 3.3-mile Salt Run Trail starts to the left of the parking when facing the hills. The 4.5-mile Wetmore Trail is across Quick Road. Connector trails lead downhill to the 1-mile Lake and 2.3-mile Cross Country trails.
audioDescription: Pine Hollow. 303 words At the side of this parking lot there is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. As you face the kiosk to your left is a paved walk leading to a building with rest rooms. On your right, the narrow parking lot stretches out in front of you and behind you. Over your left shoulder is a wide grassy slope falling away from the parking lot and edged with thick woods. Along the side of the parking lot is a row of picnic tables. On the far side of the kiosk is a board fence with signs that read, “Warming Area.” The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location in the southern part of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act.” “Pine Hollow. Kendall Hills was not part of the original Virginia Kendall Park. In 1936 the Akron Metropolitan Park District wrote to neighbor A.A. Stambaugh, vice-president of Standard Oil, offering to lease the property. Winter sports enthusiasts were spilling over from the Kendall Lake area for coasting and skiing whenever the toboggan chutes were crowded. Stambaugh said that wasn’t necessary, he was happy to see the land used. Families continue to flock here for great sledding on snowy winter days.” A sign at the bottom of the kiosk reads, “Hashtag CVNP sledding hills.” End of description.

title: Pine Lane Trailhead Information
listingDescription: Pine Lane Trailhead provides access to two of the longest trails that pass through the national park: the Buckeye and the Valley. This is a good starting point for hikers and runners who want to avoid the crowds and challenge themselves with hills.

images.altText: A two paneled bulletin board kiosk stands left of a narrow, dirt trail into yellowing trees.
images.title: Pine Lane Trailhead Kiosk
images.caption: This view of the trailhead shows the Buckeye Trail winding north into upland forest.

bodyText:
Pine Lane Trailhead is an access point for two of the longest trails in the national park. It is located at a high spot in the middle of Cuyahoga Valley, off State Route 303. This is a good choice for hikers and runners who prefer solitude, scenic views, and the physical challenge of hills. See our hiking page for trip planning information.

The Buckeye Trail makes a 1,400-mile circle across Ohio. It is managed by the Buckeye Trail Association which divides the trail into 26 sections and offers detailed maps. The route is marked by blue blazes, often painted on the trees. Hikers can enjoy day trips or plan for through-hiking. The section north from Pine Lane wanders 2.5 miles through upland forest along the east rim before crossing the valley’s floodplain in Boston. There it heads up the western valley wall to Blue Hen Falls and beyond. The south section quickly joins the Towpath Trail in Peninsula and explores the lowlands along the historic Ohio & Erie Canal. Access it by following the parking lot west to the old Pine Lane and turning right, down the old brick road.

The Valley Trail is shared by hikers and horseback riders. It goes the length of the park, connecting with other horse trails to the north and south. The Pine Lane parking lot is small and does not have designated trailer spaces. It is not an ideal starting place for riders, but some may travel through. Remember that horses always have the right of way. If hikers encounter a horse, stay visible and greet the rider. Stand off the trail and keep any pets on a short leash. Allow plenty of space to pass and avoid sudden movements. Horse trails can be muddy, so plan your footwear wisely. The section north goes through Boston in 2.4 miles, crosses the floodplain at Jaite, and continues into Brecksville Reservation. The section south connects with the Wetmore trail system in 3.8 miles and the Everett area trails beyond.

The land around this trailhead was once owned by Fred C. Kelly. Kelly was a nationally known newspaper columnist, humorist, and Wright Brothers biographer. He had a passion for conservation, helping form the first Cuyahoga Valley Association. In the 1940s, he infamously carried an axe on his walks to chop up tacky billboards along State Route 303. Pine Lane was named for all the trees he planted on his property.
audioDescription: Pine Lane Trailhead. 236 words Here at the side of the small parking lot is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. Along the right side of the kiosk an unpaved trail that a small sign identifies as Buckeye Trail leads off through the overgrown fields towards the woods at the right. On the other side of the trail is a small building with a toilet. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the middle of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place of retreat from urban life. Building on this tradition, citizens worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked Earth Day and the Clean Water Act. “Pine Lane Trailhead is between two of the longest and most remote trails found in the park: the Valley and Buckeye trails. The first is a horse trail that connects the horse trails to the south with those of Cleveland Metroparks to the north. The Buckeye Trail, part of a 1,200-mile loop around Ohio, is a favorite among local hikers and runners. It provides backcountry views, solitude, and physical challenge.” End of description.

title: Pinery Feeder
listingDescription: How do you restore a river? When two historic dams were removed at this site in 2020, the Cuyahoga became free flowing here for the first time in nearly 200 years. Learn more and find out the new method for diverting river water into the Ohio & Erie Canal via the Pinery Feeder.

images.altText: A graphic panel next to a curved paved trail; behind, an arched cement road bridge spans a river.
images.title: Pinery Feeder Panel
images.caption: A panel at the Pinery Feeder gate explains why two dams were removed from the river beyond.

bodyText:
The Pinery Feeder Dam was built in 1827 during the construction of the Ohio & Erie Canal. It consisted of a wooden crib dam, a gate, and a feeder channel. This system diverted Cuyahoga River water to “feed” the canal from Brecksville to Cuyahoga Heights. The concrete Brecksville Diversion Dam was added in 1951-52. About 120 feet north, the newer dam created a dam pool that hid the old wooden structure underwater.

Dams harm fish habitat, change water temperatures, and alter the natural flow of water and sediment through our waterways. In 2020, the National Park Service and its partners removed these dams to help wildlife recover and to make our water cleaner. After almost 200 years, the Cuyahoga once again flows freely here. A modern screw pump will help maintain the proper water level in the nearby section of canal that is designated a national historic landmark. This was the best solution for protecting both natural and cultural resources.

From here, visitors can go north or south on the Towpath Trail. To the north are the remains of Lock 36, one of many water-filled “elevators” that raised or lowered canal boats. Beyond is the Mudcatcher and a view of a bald eagle nest across the river. To the south is a connector trail to Station Road Bridge with restrooms and more exhibits.
audioDescription: Restoring the River. 474 words This wayside graphic panel at the side of a path that heads west from the Towpath Trail towards the river, crosses a feeder channel which takes water from the river to the canal, and rejoins the main trail farther south, to the right as you face the sign. Ahead of you, past the sign, is a concrete structure containing a gate which controls the flow of water through the channel into the canal. Rail tracks run along the river on the far side. A highway crosses the valley here over a multi-arched bridge which towers above you. The graphic panel has photographs of two dams which were built at this location on the river. In upper right is a black and white photograph of water spilling over the 1827 wooden Pinery Dam, located just downstream of the gate into the feeder channel. The larger photograph at the left shows the 1952 Brecksville Canal Diversion Dam, which was built slightly downstream from the older dam, and partially destroyed it, hiding its ruins under water. In both pictures the river flows smoothly over the barriers, with drops of only a few feet. Text on the panel reads, “Removing Barriers. Restoring the Cuyahoga River as a healthy, free-flowing river has many challenges. A major goal is removing dams that block fish migrations and degrade natural wildlife habitats. Here two dams diverted water into this section of the Ohio and Erie Canal, a designated national historic landmark. Park managers must balance protecting natural and cultural resources. Could engineers design a new way to water the canal without a barrier? The 1827 dam fed a canal that grew the national economy. The 1952 one provided water to downstream steel mills. What role will a healthier river play in Ohio’s economy?” In the bottom right is a map of this area, with north pointing to the right. Along the top of the map is the railroad with the river running just below it. The Brecksville-Northfield bridge runs east to west up through the middle of the map, with your current position to the left of it, just east of the river. The gate across the feeder channel is near your position, with the channel itself running to the right to meet the canal, which runs closer to the bottom of the map. The position of the two dams are indicated between the gate and the bridge. The caption reads, “After the dams are removed in 2019, a pump system will keep the most intact portions of the historic canal watered.” At the bottom of the panel are images of a rainbow darter, brightly marked with orange and turquoise, and a smallmouth bass. The caption tells us that these fish are among the species whose populations are expected to improve with the removal of the dams. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Cross the bridge, walk north on the Towpath Trail, and turn left on the loop trail to the river.
quickFacts.name: Location

Instead, a modern screw pump will divert river water into the Pinery Feeder. This will help control water levels in the longest intact section of the Ohio & Erie Canal, a national historic landmark.

title: Red Lock Trailhead
listingDescription: The Red Lock Trailhead area is a place to observe how nature is reclaiming old industrial sites and canal ruins. The small trailhead provides access to the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail, Valley Trail, and Cuyahoga River Water Trail. The area is a hotspot for birding, especially during spring migration. About a half-mile south on the towpath is the site of the Jaite Paper Mill, once a large employer in Cuyahoga Valley.

images.altText: Paved trail passes a 3-sided kiosk and brown bench at right and a brown restroom structure at left.
images.title: Red Lock Trailhead Kiosk
images.caption: A vault toilet, kiosk, and bench are close to the parking lot at Red Lock Trailhead.

bodyText:
Red Lock Trailhead is a jumping off point to recreate, relax, exercise, and learn in Cuyahoga Valley National Park. The small trailhead has fifteen parking spaces and does not accommodate over-sized vehicles. It serves several trails in the park’s interconnected trail system. Its name comes from a nearby lock on the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail.

Head out on the Towpath Trail to observe how nature is reclaiming old industrial sites and canal ruins. As you bike, walk, or jog north, look for wildlife. The area is a hotspot for birding, especially during spring migration. In 0.7 miles is the first of two intersections with the Old Carriage Trail. Turn right up a steep hill to explore the Greenwood Village site. This section is also a connector to the Bike & Hike Trail at Holzhauer Road. About a half-mile south is the site of the Jaite Paper Mill, once a large employer in Cuyahoga Valley. The mill made paper, provided jobs, and shaped local communities. The buildings are gone, and the land is being restored through contaminant removal and native plantings.

The Valley Trail offers a more secluded trail experience. This hiking and horse trail follows the Towpath south before veering to the left beyond the former paper mill. To head north on the trail, cross the Cuyahoga River on Vaughn Road. The entrance to the trail is on your right.

Walk further along Vaughn Road to reach a 0.7-mile connector hiking trail. It leads to Jaite, once the company town for the paper mill and now National Park Service headquarters. From the connector, cross Riverview Road and walk briefly along Snowville Road to find the Buckeye Trail, a long-distance hiking trail that heads both north and south from Snowville.

Red Lock Trailhead also serves the Cuyahoga River Water Trail. A gravel access drive adjacent to the Vaughn Road bridge allows for equipment drop off close to the river. Learn more at Red Lock Trailhead River Access.
audioDescription: Red Lock Trailhead. 436 words A three-sided, covered kiosk with a bulletin board and two graphic panels sits at the side a paved path which leads from a small parking lot to the Towpath Trail. If you stand with your back to the parking lot, there is a small building with restrooms on the left side of the path in front of you and a bench next to the kiosk on the right side. There are woods on both sides of the path and the parking lot. One of the graphic panels is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Red Lock Trailhead. The Red Lock area is a place to observe how nature is reclaiming old industrial sites and canal ruins. As you bike, walk, or jog north, look for wildlife. The area is a hotspot for birding, especially during spring migration. About a half-mile south is the site of the Jaite Paper Mill, once a large employer in Cuyahoga Valley. The buildings are gone and the land is being restored through contaminant removal and native plantings.” The third side has a panel titled “Ohio and Erie Canalway” with a large black and white photograph of three mules pulling a canal boat on the canal. Smaller photographs show the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad, a group of children riding bicycles on the towpath, and the scenic byway that winds through the valley. A long map down the right side shows mileage between trailheads on the Towpath Trail. Text on the panel reads, “The Ohio and Erie Canalway celebrates the first 110 miles of a waterway that helped the nation grow. Dug by hand from 1825 to 1832, the Ohio and Erie Canal was the first canal west of the Appalachian Mountains. It connected Lake Erie to the Ohio River, providing a key link in an interstate shipping route. People and products flowed across America. Canal towns became major commercial centers. Ohio grew in population and wealth. Today you can explore the lasting impact of this historic public works project. Travel along the Canalway’s three spines. Discover how culture, recreation, and natural scenic beauty are being revitalized by this national heritage area.” End of description.

title: Red Lock Trailhead River Access
listingDescription: Access the river from the south side of the Vaughn Road bridge over the Cuyahoga River. This bridge is located near Red Lock Trailhead in Northfield.

images.altText: Next to a bridge is a thin, grassy trail that leads down to the Cuyahoga River
images.title: Red Lock Trailhead River Access Point
images.caption: Just off of West Highland Road is this Cuyahoga River access point for paddlers.

bodyText:
This site allows access to a section of the Cuyahoga River Water Trail that is suitable for beginners.

Things to Know for Paddlers

  • Paved parking lot, pit toilet, hiking and biking trail.
  • Dropoff in the gravel access drive at the southeast corner of the Vaughn/Highland Road bridge. Park at Red Lock Trailhead.
  • Dropoff/pickup 250 feet from water’s edge (longer than usual).
  • Pedal/Paddle option. Use the Towpath Trail to bike/run/walk back from Station Road Bridge trailhead.
  • Class I downstream paddle to Station Road Bridge Trailhead involves no permanent hazards.
audioDescription: Red Lock River Access. 205 words The Cuyahoga River Water Trail access at Red Lock is located on the east bank at the southeast corner of the West Highland Road bridge. Park at Red Lock Trailhead. Follow the bath past the information kiosk and restroom to the Towpath Trail. Turn left past the canal lock and cross the road. Immediately turn right onto the dirt trail to the river access. It runs parallel to the bridge and slopes downward. At the access point, the river will be in front of you. The last rock step leads directly into the water. The terrain to the right consists of large rocks that lead into the river. The vehicle bridge is to your right. The terrain to your left is steep, with grass and trees. To the left and behind you, the back of the water trail sign is visible. The front of the sign is dark blue, showing the Cuyahoga River Water Trail logo with “Red Lock Vaughn Road.” Underneath the text is a lighter blue area with the number “24.1”—indicating the river mile. Across the river to the left is a flat area on the west bank. The terrain is flat with a downward slope. End Description.

title: Restoring the Cuyahoga River Exhibits
listingDescription: Near the Station Road Bridge Trailhead, several exhibits tell the Cuyahoga’s remarkable story of recovery. Wildlife is returning to a river famous for catching fire. Listen and read how local people made this happen. Pose for photos with our eagle and heron statues.

images.altText: Two graphic panels, statue of eagle on a log, & tall blue heron statue beside paved trail in snow.
images.title: Restoring the Cuyahoga River Exhibits
images.caption: The exhibits greet visitors as they approach the Station Road Bridge from the parking area.

bodyText:
The Cuyahoga River story is one of redemption, change, recovery, and contrast. The 100-mile river’s headwaters are only 30 miles from its mouth. It travels southwest before turning north. It flows through farmlands, woodlands, suburbs, and cities. The Cuyahoga was once so polluted that it caught fire many times, downstream in Cleveland’s shipping channel. The infamous 1969 blaze helped spark the Clean Water Act, the formation of the US Environmental Protection Agency, and other milestones in the environmental movement. Established soon after in 1974, our national park plays an important role in restoring and protecting the Cuyahoga.

As water quality has improved, fish and the native wildlife that eat fish have come back. Just north of Station Road Bridge is a former heronry where Cuyahoga Valley’s first baby bald eagle fledged in 2007. As you explore the area, look for other signs of recovery: river otters, great blue herons, prothonotary warblers, aquatic turtles, hikers, cyclists, and paddlers. The metal sculpture by Michael Maras is called Return to the River (Cuyahoga Valley National Park). It was dedicated during the Xtinguish Torch Fest in 2019 to celebrate the river’s amazing progress 50 years after the 1969 fire. It reminds us that we can make a difference when we work together.

This exhibit cluster also includes several panels, an audio player with an attached script, a tactile model of a sport fish called muskellunge (or “muskie”), and a tactile model of a bald eagle eating a carp.

From here, you can further explore the river as well as the Ohio & Erie Canal by crossing east over the bridge to the Towpath Trail. Make two quick lefts to see the place where the Brecksville Diversion Dam was removed in 2020. Turn right to head south toward Red Lock Trailhead.

At the yellow Brecksville Station, you can catch Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad or take advantage of the accessible restrooms and drinking water, available year-round.
audioDescription: Restoring the Cuyahoga River. 494 words Here there is a 6-foot-tall, two-sided graphic panel standing next to a touchable model of an eagle perched on a log eating a large carp. On the other side of the log display is a slanted, wayside graphic panel and a metal post with audio. At the end is a 7-foot metal sculpture of a heron on a branch with fish and mayflies below. As you face the tall panel with the log model to the right, the parking lot is behind you and the Brecksville Station is to the left on the far side of the train tracks. Ahead of you on the far side of the panel is the historic Station Road Bridge over the Cuyahoga River. Text on the tall panel reads, “The 100-mile Cuyahoga River is modest in length by mighty in its impact on the environmental movement. Like many others, the river became badly polluted by industrial waste and sewage. Floating debris and chemicals caught fire near its mouth in Cleveland many times starting in 1868. The fire on June 22, 1969, finally caught the nation’s attention. The outcry stimulated new environmental laws and enforcement agencies. Because of the resulting Clean Water Act 1972, rivers throughout the nation are better protected. More funding allows communities to provide residents with safe, clean water. Ironically, local pride in the Cuyahoga’s comeback is often celebrated with ‘burning river’ event and products.” To the left of the text is a photograph of a river fire in 1952, huge clouds of black smoke billowing upwards. At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of kayakers floating down today’s river through tree-lined banks. The eagle on the log to the right of the panel sits with its tail towards the left. It leans over to eat a large fish lying at the right. The wayside panel farther to the right is titled “Fish Reveal River’s Health.” At the bottom of this panel is a touchable 19-inch-long model of a muskie, a long narrow sport fish, mounted with its mouth at the left. Text on the panel reads in part, “Fish tell us the Cuyahoga River is getting healthier. They are coming back due to improved water quality and removal of dams that block migration. Restoring natural flow improves the river bottom habitat for insects and other small animals. That means more food for fish – and more fish for hungry eagles, herons, otters, and people.” The panel also has a picture of two river otters and a bald eagle on its nest. The audio station to the right of the wayside has four buttons that play audio segments on the River Restoration. From left to right they are Oily Waste in the River, 55 seconds; Making a Comeback, 60 seconds; Paddling the River, 50 seconds; and Bald Eagle Success Story, 40 seconds. The sign on the heron statue says “Return to the River by Michael Marras, 2019 Xtinguish Celebration.” End of description.

title: Ritchie Ledges Panel
listingDescription: The Ledges create a high point in the valley uplands. Learn the basics of their geology at the Ritchie Ledges wayside. It describes how periodically fast-moving streams flowed through a steamy swamp about 315-320 million years ago. The streams brought sand and pebbles that formed the Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate rock that we see today.

images.altText: “Ritchie Ledges” panel stands along an unpaved trail surrounded by tree trunks and fallen leaves.
images.title: Ritchie Ledges Panel
images.caption: A panel along the Ledges Trail explains the rock formation’s geology.

bodyText:
The Ledges create a high point in the valley uplands. Discover the basic geology at the Ritchie Ledges graphic panel. It describes how water and weathering shaped the rock.

About 315-320 million years ago, the area was steamy swamp. Periodically fast-moving streams dropped sand and pebbles here. Over time, this material was compacted into rock called Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate. Erosion has carved the rock into the forms you see today.

Like a sponge, the rock absorbs rainfall between the grains of sand and pebbles. This water makes the Ledges cooler and moister than its surroundings. More northern plants and animals can thrive here. Look for evergreen eastern hemlock trees and listen for the cheery, buzzy song of black-throated green warblers. Take a moment to enjoy the coolness and beauty of this microclimate.

Life on the Ledges is fragile. Mosses and ferns cling to sand and pebble crevices. Please help us protect this fragile life by enjoying the Ledges from the trail. A moment of rock climbing, which is not allowed, can erase years of growth.

Learn more about the geology of the Cuyahoga Valley.
audioDescription: The Ritchie Ledges. 372 words This wayside graphic panel sits at an intersection where two trails on top of the Ledges plateau cross each other. All around are thick woods, deciduous trees mixed with evergreen hemlocks. A sign post tells us that the Ledges Shelter is one-quarter mile to the left as you face the graphic panel, the Octagon is one-third mile straight ahead, while going in the other direction leads to the Ledges Trail, a long loop which circles this entire geologic formation. At the opposite side of the crossroads is a bench. The panel has a map of the entire Ledges, an oval shaped area with your current location a third of the way from the right end. The Ledges Shelter lies to the left with the Overlook and a trail to Kendall Lake at the far left. At top of the map is the trail to the Octagon. At bottom, a trail passes the Ice Box Cave and skirts the rocky cliffs along that edge. At far right, a side trail leads to the Happy Days Lodge. Text on the panel reads, “As you wander through the unusual environment of the Ritchie Ledges, you will encounter evidence of an ancient landscape, one that has witnessed great changes in climate and terrain. You will be exploring the remnants of primeval stream beds deposited when the area was a steamy swamp 320 million years ago. Over time, these sand and pebble sediments were compacted into rock, now called Sharon Conglomerate. Erosion has carved the rock into the form you see today. Life on the Ritchie Ledges is fragile. Soil on the rocks is thin and root systems are very shallow. Please enjoy the beauty of the Ledges from the trail. A moment of thoughtless rock climbing can erase years of growth.” At upper right is a drawing of small hemlock branches with seed cones at the tips. The caption reads, “The Ledges are cooler and moister than the surrounding area, attracting plants and animals adapted to this microenvironment. Evergreen eastern hemlocks, shown here, are perhaps the most striking of these. They hint of a time when their kind thrived in the cooler, moister climate that followed glacial retreat 14,000 years ago.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Ledges Trailhead, 405 Truxell Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Hike north past the shelter on the Ledges Trail.
