title: Rockside Station
listingDescription: Passengers in the Cleveland area can catch the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad at Rockside Station. This also provides overflow parking for visitors accessing the Towpath Trail and the Cuyahoga River Water Trail at Lock 39 Trailhead. The station has ample parking and is a primary starting point for train excursions and events.

images.altText: Park sign at the entrance to a large parking lot. On the right side is a yellow train station.
images.title: CVSR Rockside Station
images.caption: Rockside is the closest Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad station to Cleveland.

bodyText:
Passengers in the Cleveland area can catch Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad at Rockside Station. The station has ample parking and is a primary starting point for train excursions and events.

Historically, Thornburg Station once stood nearby and served Independence, Ohio. Small train depots were found all along the Cuyahoga Valley Line at every little hamlet of any size. In the early 2000s, the National Park Service built the modern Rockside Station for passengers waiting for the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad.

Visions for a train line through the valley began in the 1850s. Competition and economic slumps delayed its completion until 1880. This became the shortest route between Akron and the coalfields of Tuscarawas County to the south and Cleveland’s ports in the north. For the valley, these train stations were a lifeline to the outside world. They provided passenger service and allowed farmers to ship out their milk, cheese, grain, and lumber. Exhibits inside the station describe the area’s railroad history in more depth.

From this point, visitors can get on the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad or head east over the river to access the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail and Cuyahoga River Water Trail at Lock 39 Trailhead.
audioDescription: Rockside Station. 470 words The rail station is a long rectangular covered platform with a wall at each end and a small office in the middle. Posts along each side support the shingled roof. Wooden benches sit on either side of the office. The floor is made of wood boards and the structure is painted a creamy yellow. On one side of the station is an asphalt parking lot. On the other side of the parking lot a bridge crosses the river and leads to the towpath. The railroad tracks are on the other side of the station past a wide grassy ditch. Wooden walkways over the ditch at either end of the station provide access to the train platform. If you stand with your back to the parking lot, restrooms are in a separate building at the left end of the station. Graphic panels are hung on the inside of the end walls. At one end is a panel titled “Ride the Rails” which explains that the first steam engine in the valley began running in 1880 connecting the mineral fields in the south to the factories in the north. Today the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad follows much of the same route. Yellow paint on a station signifies a modern building. Historical depots are painted red. The panel shows a map of the rail line through Cuyahoga Valley National Park, stretching from Rockside Station at the northern end (your current location) to the Akron Northside Station at the southern end. The railroad and the Towpath Trail both follow the Cuyahoga River through the park. At the same end of the station is a glass-covered bulletin board with current information about the train and the park. The wall at the other end has two graphic panels. One is titled “Industrial Cleveland.” It has a black and white photograph of Cleveland from 1895 and one of the Standard Oil refinery. Text on the panel explains that by the late 1800s, petroleum refining, steel making, chemical processing, and machine-tool production made the city a thriving economic center. Prominent businessmen served on the Valley Railway’s board of directors. A photograph of Stillman Witt, a partner in a railroad construction company, is to the right of the text. The other panel is titled “Route to the Coalfields” with a photograph of a group of almost 50 miners at the entrance of a mine operated by the Marchesi Coal Company in Tuscarawas County. A railroad map of Ohio from 1873 with a band down the eastern side shows the location of an iron ore belt. Text on the panel explains that the developers of the railway capitalized on the need for a direct rail line between the new fields in Tuscarawas and Stark counties to the south and the industrial centers of Cleveland and Akron. End of description.

quickFacts.value: 7900 Old Rockside Road, Independence, Ohio 44131
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Rockside Station is the primary boarding site for Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad near Cleveland. Its design reflects historic depots that were once found throughout the valley, connecting local people to the outside world. Milk, cheese, grain, and lumber went out. Mail, news, and manufactured goods came in.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Valley Railway Historic District, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: South Park Exhibits
listingDescription: South Park Village was on a bluff across the river from these exhibits. Prehistoric people of the Whittlesey Tradition lived here from 1000 to 1600.

images.altText: The historical marker is left of the panel. They overlook a meadow with a forested valley wall.
images.title: South Park Exhibit Photo
images.caption: A Whittlesey village was on a bluff across from this Ohio historical marker and graphic panel.

bodyText:
The land around you has a long history of human occupation. From 1000 to about 400 years ago, a thriving village bustled with life on the bluff across the Cuyahoga River. It was occupied, abandoned, and re-occupied many times during those six centuries. Archeologists call the culture that lived there the Whittlesey Tradition. Colonel Charles Whittlesey was the first to scientifically describe their sites. Whittlesey lifeways resembled the Fort Ancient culture of the Ohio River Valley. Archeologists identify the Whittlesey Tradition by their unique pottery and points.

These people lived in a walled village, and used the fields around you to cultivate corn, beans, and squash. Those foods were eaten with meat from deer, elk, bear and other game as well as foods from the river. We learn about past people from what they leave behind. What will we leave behind and what will it say about us?

Note that it is illegal to collect artifacts or disturb archeological sites within the national park.
audioDescription: South Park Exhibits. 412 words At the side of the towpath are two panels. One is a small, free-standing graphic panel titled “Late-Prehistoric Period.” The other is a 2-sided, metal Ohio Historical Marker mounted on a post. The historical marker has raised lettering. Both sides have the same text. On the other side of the signs is a field with trees covering a low ridge along the river at the far end. As you face the signs, the canal is behind you with the scenic byway on the other side. Text on the historical marker reads, “South Park Village and the Whittlesey Tradition. Directly across the Cuyahoga River from this spot is the South Park Village. Here, archeologists uncovered the remains of a four-acre Native American settlement populated by people of the Whittlesey Tradition. The people of South Park lived in communal structures and grew maize, beans, and squash in the floodplain fields that surround you. Food remains found in the village excavations reveal that they hunted deer, elk, black bear, and other game and gathered clams and fish from the Cuyahoga River. South Park was abandoned and reoccupied several times between A.D. 1000 and 1600. Numerous seasonal campsites have been found on the floodplains and terraces on both side of the river. The first localized cultural development unique to this area, Whittlesey sites have been identified upriver from here in Summit County and in the Chagrin and Grand River valleys to the east. The Ohio Bicentennial Commission, The Ohio Historical Society, 2004.” The graphic panel features an artist’s drawing of the South Park village. A circular fence made of vertical logs surrounds seven Quonset-hut-like houses, long structures with a semi-circular cross section. At upper right is a picture of a pot found at South Park, a deep vessel with a rounded bottom. Text on the panel reads, “Whittlesey Villagers. Beginning around 1000, American Indians in northeastern Ohio developed a distinctive culture known archeologically as the Whittlesey Tradition. They started building walls around their small villages. Their pottery and agriculture changed, too. Instead of having a complex trade network, they relied on the local landscape. Imagine what it was like to live in the long, multi-family homes made of wooden poles. What kinds of vegetables did they raise on the floodplain? By the time European explorers arrived in the early 1700s, these Whittlesey Tradition people had disappeared from the Cuyahoga Valley. This late-prehistoric culture is named for the archeologist Charles Whittlesey, 1808-1886.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125 and hike north on the Towpath Trail
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Whittlesey Tradition people lived in Northeast Ohio during the Middle Woodland period. Nearby South Park Village was a significant site that has been heavily impacted by modern human use.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network

title: Stanford House
listingDescription: Built in 1843 by George Stanford, the Stanford House offers accommodations to groups and visitors through the Conservancy for Cuyahoga Valley National Park.

images.altText: A historic white house with green shutters and door sits atop a low hill, surrounded by tall trees.
images.title: Stanford House Exterior
images.caption: View of Stanford House from the front lawn.

bodyText:
James Stanford – one of the original settlers of the Western Reserve and surveyor for the Connecticut Land Company – claimed this land in 1806. Legend tells us that he suggested the name of Boston when the village decided to incorporate. Sadly, he didn’t live to see Boston become a bustling canal town.

His oldest son, George, no doubt profited from the canal. He built this Greek Revival house in 1843 and expanded the family farm to 283 acres by 1853.  Over time, the family had sheep, dairy cattle, orchards, timber, and grain. Besides farming, George and his son ran a lumber business on the property.

Today, the Conservancy for Cuyahoga Valley National Park offers overnight accommodations for individuals and groups in a restored Stanford House. The building’s interior reflects its historic character while also featuring furnishings crafted locally from sustainable and reclaimed materials. The house is normally closed to the public, except for lodging and for special programs.

The grounds of Stanford House have picnic tables for outdoor gatherings. Across Stanford Road from the house, the Stanford Connector leads to the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail. A 0.4-mile trail heads around the pond and to Hines Hill Conference Center. The 1.5-mile Stanford Trail starts behind the barn and leads to Brandywine Falls.
audioDescription: Stanford House. 313 words This white frame house is in the shape of an “L.” The section at left is two stories with two rows of three windows with green shutters. A smaller window is under the peak of the gable at top. The section of the house that stretches to the right is lower, the peak of its roof just fitting under the eaves of the other section. There are half-height windows on the upper floor just under the roofline. In the corner of the “L” is a covered porch leading to the door. A wayside graphic panel is located at the right end of the sidewalk which leads from the driveway to the porch. To the right of the house is a small garage building with a parking area in front. To the left, the driveway runs down a slight slope to the road. Behind you as you face the panel is a large grassy lawn with a very large barn at the side away from the road. The background of the panel shows a drawing of the Stanford farm circa 1870s. The house is shown at an angle, paralleling the road. A plain, white rail fence surrounds the house and barn. A man and a woman play croquet on the lawn. Text on the panel reads, “James Stanford – one of the original settlers of the Western Reserve and surveyor for the Connecticut Land Company – claimed this land in 1806. His oldest son, George, built this house in 1843 and expanded the family farm to 283 acres by 1853. Besides farming, George and his son ran a lumber business on the property. “Today, the Conservancy for Cuyahoga Valley National Park offers overnight accommodations for individuals and groups in a restored Stanford House. The building’s interior reflects its historic character while also featuring furnishings crafted locally from sustainable and reclaimed materials.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: 6093 Stanford Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264 (limited parking)
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Stanford House is on the National Register of Historic Places. The house was built during the heyday of the Canal Era, reflecting the wealth and resources the Ohio & Erie Canal both brought in and transported out of the valley.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Stanford Trailhead
listingDescription: Stanford Trailhead is a small, unpaved parking area for Stanford Trail. This 1.5-mile trail leads up the side of the valley to Brandywine Falls. The parking also serves Stanford House, an overnight facility operated by the Conservancy for Cuyahoga Valley National Park.

images.altText: Under a tree, a dirt path snakes between a roofed bulletin board and an old brick chicken coop.
images.title: Stanford Trailhead Bulletin Board
images.caption: The trailhead bulletin board and parking are located behind the barn.

bodyText:
Stanford Trailhead is a small parking area for Stanford Trail. The 1.5-mile woodland trail leads to Brandywine Falls. Be prepared for steep hills and unpaved, potentially muddy surfaces. As you get close to the waterfall, you’ll see the Brandywine Gorge Trail on your left. It provides an alternate route to the waterfall with up-close views of Brandywine Creek. The parking also serves Stanford House, an overnight facility operated by the Conservancy for Cuyahoga Valley National Park.

Stanford Trailhead sits behind a large red barn that was part of the Stanford family farm. It is a raised three-bay barn, also known as an English barn. The second floor was used for processing and storing grains. The basement, which may have been added later, housed livestock. Dairying was part of the Stanford farm operations.
audioDescription: Stanford Trailhead. 224 words Here is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. Along the right side of the kiosk an unpaved trail leads off through the overgrown fields. On the other side of the path is a small block building and a large tree. As you face the kiosk, behind you is a large wooden barn. To the left is a dirt parking lot next to a white house. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location near the middle of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place of retreat from urban life. Building on this tradition, citizens worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked Earth Day and the Clean Water Act. “Stanford Trailhead. Named for James Stanford who came here in 1805 to farm on Ohio’s frontier, the relatively short Stanford Trail is steep in places and provides a moderate challenge to hiking enthusiasts. Trail connections lead to the scenic Brandywine Falls, the most popular attraction in Cuyahoga Valley National Park.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: 6093 Stanford Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264 (limited parking)
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Stanford Trailhead provides parking for Stanford House and a popular trail to Brandywine Falls.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: National Register of Historic Places; Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Station Road Bridge Exhibits
listingDescription: The wrought-iron Station Road Bridge was built over the Cuyahoga River in 1881. It provided vehicle access to the Cuyahoga Valley Line at Brecksville Station. This train station and its bridge were a vital link between Cuyahoga and Summit counties, improving travel between Cleveland and Akron. Today, the bridge serves hikers, horseback riders, and cyclists. Two exhibit panels interpret the Pinery Narrows bridges and the Cuyahoga River.

images.altText: An iron bridge over a river with Pinery Narrows panel showing a distant concrete bridge bring built.
images.title: Station Road Bridge Exhibits
images.caption: An outdoor exhibit interprets the view north from the Station Road Bridge over the Cuyahoga River.

bodyText:
The Pinery Narrows is considered the skinniest part of the Cuyahoga River gorge. It got its name from the pine trees that once grew atop the deeply cut bedrock. Here two bridges cross the Cuyahoga River, bringing Summit and Cuyahoga counties together. The oldest is the 1881 Station Road Bridge. It was built of wrought iron in the style of a railroad bridge, using both older and newer technologies. Photographers love the arched Brecksville-Northfield High Level Bridge that dominates the view. Concrete was a relatively new construction material when it was built in 1931.

The river that re-carved these narrows has an unusual shape. It flows south from its headwaters in Geauga County until it hits Akron’s bedrock. There it turns sharply north, burrowing into a pre-glacial riverbed. This U-turn gives the river its name: Cuyahoga, after an Iroquoian word for curve or jawbone. The ridge it hits at Akron forms a continental divide, with water south of it flowing toward the Ohio and Mississippi rivers, and the water north flowing into Lake Erie at Cleveland. Cuyahoga Valley lies between the cities. The river and its terraces form the bottomlands. Steep ravines and rock ledges define the uplands on either side.
audioDescription: Station Road Bridge. 486 words This narrow bridge over the Cuyahoga River has a superstructure made of iron truss with a roadway made of wood. A path from one end of the bridge leads east through woods to the Towpath Trail alongside the canal. From the other end of the bridge, paths lead to the Brecksville train station. Railroad tracks parallel the river on that side. There are two wayside graphic panels along the north side of the bridge, which faces downstream, giving a view of the elevated, multi-arched bridge over the entire valley. The left graphic panel is titled “Pinery Narrows, Bridging the Valley.” Text on the panel tells us that you are on the 1881 wrought-iron Station Road Bridge facing the Pinery Narrows, the Cuyahoga Valley’s thinnest point. Here the river is confined by hard, deeply cut bedrock. Ahead of you is the 1931 Brecksville-Northfield High-Level Bridge, built to replace the bridge on which you are standing. At the lower left of the panel is an early 1900s photograph of the view looking north from here before the newer bridge was built. The main photograph on the panel shows a view of the concrete arches of the new bridge, one filled with wooden scaffolding. On a dirt road below is an old model car. The caption reads, “In 1931 area residents took day trips to admire the Brecksville-Northfield Bridge as it was nearing completion.” The other panel is titled “Cuyahoga River, Carving a Crooked Path.” The right side of the panel has an aerial photograph showing the river making several sharp “S” bends as it flows through green fields and woods. On the left side is a touchable map with braille labels of the “U” shaped route of the Cuyahoga River. Start in the upper left corner to feel the recessed area of Lake Erie. The river flows into the lake at Cleveland marked with a raised square. Follow the river down, past a major tributary on the right, to a raised star, marking your current location. Continue down to find the curve to the right and upwards. Just below that is a small raised circle at Akron. The depressed area on both sides of the river marks the watershed. The caption tells us the Cuyahoga River collects the waters of 37 tributaries and many unnamed streams providing water for nearly 15 percent of Ohio’s population. Text on the panel reads in part, “The Cuyahoga River changes direction in its 100-mile course. It flows southwest until it meets a north-south ridge – a continental divide – at Akron. There it turns north and empties into Lake Erie, about 30 miles west of where it began. … The national park’s terrain consists of river terraces, steep valleys, ravines, and rock ledges. Bedrock includes several layers of shale … and Berea sandstone.” Below the text are touchable rock samples. Clockwise from the top is granite, sandstone, and shale. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Walk to the wrought iron bridge.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Both bridges are historically significant, blending new and old technologies. Notice the wrought iron and rivets, and the concrete and arches. This spot is one of the most iconic places to view the Cuyahoga River and glimpse Cuyahoga Valley’s steep walls.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Lake Erie Birding Trail; Industrial Heartland Network; Ohio to Erie Trail; Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Station Road Bridge River Access
listingDescription: Access the river via the Station Road Bridge Trailhead in Brecksville. A mowed path leads from the southeast corner of the parking lot to the river.

images.altText: A green kayak rests by a trail sign overlooking the junction of two waterways. Two people pull an or
images.title: Station Road Bridge River Access
images.caption: The boat access on the Cuyahoga River just upstream of Station Road Bridge.

bodyText:
This site allows access to a section of the Cuyahoga River Water Trail that is suitable for beginners. A mowed path leads from the southeast corner of the parking lot to the river. Two dams were removed downstream in 2020, improving paddler safety and lowering the water level here.

Things to Know for Paddlers

  • Paved parking lot, restrooms, picnic tables, drinking water, hiking and biking trails, train station.
  • River-related exhibits near the trailhead kiosk and along the Towpath Trail.
  • View of Station Road Bridge is popular with photographers.
  • Dropoff/pickup option on Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad during Bike Aboard season with fee. Board downstream at Rockside Station and ride to Brecksville Station. Paddle to Lock 39 (located next to Rockside Station), walk to Rockside Station parking lot and drive back to pick up your boat.
  • Pedal/paddle option. Use the Towpath Trail to bike/run/walk back from Lock 39 Trailhead.
  • Class I downstream paddle to Lock 39 involves one permanent hazard.

Known Hazards

Downstream:

  • Before Lock 39 Trailhead, tall metal pylons in the river can create log jams. Portage right if needed. Know the river flow before you go. Check river gauges.
audioDescription: Station Road Bridge River Access. 244 words The Cuyahoga River Water Trail access at Station Road Bridge is located on the west bank of the river. The mowed path to the river access starts in the southeast corner of the parking lot at Station Road Bridge Trailhead. There is a sign at the beginning that states vehicles are prohibited. Closer to the river access is another sign that provides directions on “River Use and Hazards.” The access point is to the left of the sign. There are large rocks to use as stepping stones down to the riverbank. The terrain is flat through the field and becomes uneven as you approach the river access. The path does get muddy after wet weather. When you reach the access point, the river will be in front of you. The ground is dirt with different sized rocks along the bank. The area to the direct right and left of the access point is steep and has grass and trees. The Towpath Trail is visible directly across the river. Station Road Bridge is visible downriver to your left. To your right is an open flat area with loose rocks and dirt with Chippewa Creek beyond. To the right and behind you is a dark blue sign that has the Cuyahoga River Water Trail logo with “Station Road Bridge.” Underneath the text on the sign is a lighter blue shaded area with the number “21.0” indicating the river mile. End of Description

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Follow the marked path southeast to the river.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Provides paddlers with access to the Cuyahoga River Water Trail.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Cuyahoga River Water Trail

title: Station Road Bridge Trailhead Information
listingDescription: Brecksville Station was once a loading point for outgoing milk and lumber on the Valley Railway. Now this area is a crossroads for rail passengers, hikers, cyclists, runners, paddlers, and horse riders. Here, Station Road Bridge Trailhead provides ample parking and access to the Towpath Trail, Cuyahoga River Water Trail, and Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad. In spring and summer, this is a hotspot for birders who flock to see cerulean and yellow-throated warblers.

images.altText: Yellow train station & tracks to left of distant arched bridge in snow, three-sided kiosk at right.
images.title: Station Road Bridge Trailhead
images.caption: The trailhead information kiosk, right, near the Brecksville Station and exhibits about the river.

bodyText:
The Station Road Bridge Trailhead has been a crossroads since the early 1880s. The Valley Railway opened in 1880 and included Brecksville Station as a stop in this location. Produce such as milk and cheese, lumber, and finished products could be shipped out from both Summit and Cuyahoga Counties on the train. By 1882, the wrought iron bridge crossed the Cuyahoga River and provided access to the Ohio & Erie Canal.

Now this area is a crossroads for rail passengers, hikers, cyclists, runners, paddlers, and horse riders. Here, Station Road Bridge Trailhead provides ample parking. People can access the Ohio & Erie Canal Towpath Trail, Cuyahoga River Water Trail, and Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad. A connector trail along the entrance drive leads to Cleveland Metroparks’ Brecksville Reservation. Two long-distance trails pass through Brecksville Reservation and use the Towpath Trail north of Station Road Bridge. They include the Buckeye Trail for hikers and the Valley Trail for hikers and horses.

The Station Road Bridge Trailhead is also a destination for people who enjoy nature, history, and scenery. In spring and summer, this is a hotspot for birders who flock to see cerulean and yellow-throated warblers. Cross the historic Station Road Bridge for scenic views of the Cuyahoga River. Follow the towpath north about a half-mile to see ruins of Ohio & Erie Canal Lock 36 and the Mudcatcher beyond.
audioDescription: Station Road Bridge Trailhead. 446 words A three-sided, covered kiosk with a bulletin board and two graphic panels sits at the side of the parking lot. If you face the kiosk with your back to the parking lot, the Brecksville Station is to the left on the far side of the train tracks and, in front of you, a path leads to a historic bridge over the river and connects to the Towpath Trail along the canal. One of the graphic panels is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location at the northern end of the park marked. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Station Road Bridge Trailhead. Brecksville Station was once a loading point for outgoing milk and lumber. Now this area is a crossroads for rail passengers, hikers, cyclists, runners, paddlers, and horse riders. In spring and summer, this is a hotspot for birders who flock to see cerulean and yellow-throated warblers. Cross the historic Station Road Bridge for scenic views of the Cuyahoga River. Follow the towpath north about a half-mile to Lock 36’s ruins and the Mudcatcher beyond. Loop back via the trail along the river.” The third side has a panel titled “Ohio and Erie Canalway” with a large black and white photograph of three mules pulling a canal boat on the canal. Smaller photographs show the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad, a group of children riding bicycles on the towpath, and the scenic byway that winds through the valley. A long map down the right side shows mileage between trailheads on the Towpath Trail. Text on the panel reads, “The Ohio and Erie Canalway celebrates the first 110 miles of a waterway that helped the nation grow. Dug by hand from 1825 to 1832, the Ohio and Erie Canal was the first canal west of the Appalachian Mountains. It connected Lake Erie to the Ohio River, providing a key link in an interstate shipping route. People and products flowed across America. Canal towns became major commercial centers. Ohio grew in population and wealth. Today you can explore the lasting impact of this historic public works project. Travel along the Canalway’s three spines. Discover how culture, recreation and natural scenic beauty are being revitalized by this national heritage area.” End of description.

quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The area is a major crossroads, both historically for commerce and today for recreation.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Tavern and Store Panel
listingDescription: Canal Exploration Center was once a rest stop on the Ohio & Erie Canal. The Gleasons ran a tavern and a store in this building in the mid-1800s.

images.altText: A graphic panel and life ring stand ouside a white historic building with a porch and an M-shaped
images.title: Tavern and Store Panel Photo
images.caption: Canal Exploration Center was a rest stop at Lock 38.

bodyText:
This building has witnessed many changes through the years. Documents reveal that Ma Parker had her tavern on or near this location by the time of canal construction. Artifacts uncovered here also suggest this was a pre-canal tavern. The original building was the southern half of the structure. By 1841, Moses Gleason bought the property and sold it to his son. Isaac Gleason added the southern part of the building, turning it into a store serving travelers waiting at Lock 38. The Gleason family continued to live here until the early 1900s. After that, the building became a residence and later housed a blacksmith shop. As the building wore down, it became a multi-resident structure.

The National Park Service purchased the property and began historic reconstruction in the early 1990s. In 1996 it opened as Canal Visitor Center. Today it operates as Canal Exploration Center, where visitors can explore Ohio & Erie Canal history through hands-on exhibits.
audioDescription: Tavern and Store. 390 words At the side of the wide towpath, to the right of a graphic panel, is a two-story, white-frame building that looks like two houses stuck together. Each side has a peaked gable over its front and dark green shutters at the windows. The left section of the building had a covered porch along its front with a double door in the middle and a window on either side. On the left side of the porch is a bench. A barrel sits to the right of the doors. The ground slopes down along the left side of the building, revealing a stone basement. In front of the left end of the building is a lifesaver ring hanging from a post. The right section of the building has a single door at its left side and two windows to the right. A water-filled lock is on the other side of the towpath with large, functioning wooden gates. Exercise caution near the lock as there is no guardrail. Text on the graphic panel reads, “Canal Rest Stop. In the mid-1800s, the Gleason family ran a tavern and store in this building. Here boat crews and passengers could get something to eat and drink. They also could buy supplies such as tea, sugar, tobacco, needles, and thread. Tour the exhibits in the old tavern-store. Decide for yourself whether building the Ohio and Erie Canal was worth the tax dollars.” The lower right of the panel shows a color illustration of a canal boat approaching the tavern and store on the left. The lock gates stand open to receive the boat. At the rear of the boat is a dark-skinned man in a top hat and long black coat. The caption reads, “John Malvin, a free black from Virginia, became a businessman and civic leader in Cleveland. This scene shows Malvin in about 1853 as the captain of the ‘Auburn.’ His crew included both blacks and whites.” At the bottom left is a photograph from around 1910 of the tavern and store building, looking much as it does today except for a smaller building at the back-left corner. The caption reads, “After the canal era, the building became a residence and later housed a blacksmith shop. Notice that the building on the left – probably a barn – is no longer there.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: This twin-peaked structure has been here at least as long as the Ohio & Erie Canal. It originally served as a tavern for passengers weary of canal boat travel. Later it was a store. In the 1900s it became a residence, a blacksmith shop, and then multiple residences.

title: Tinkers Creek Aqueduct
listingDescription: Why is there a bridge for water? This aqueduct carries the Ohio & Erie Canal over Tinkers Creek.

images.altText: A woman in a raincoat reads a graphic panel by a stream.
images.title: Tinkers Creek Aqueduct Photo
images.caption: The aqueduct is on the far side of the Towpath Trail bridge over Tinkers Creek.

bodyText: A canal needs a specific level of water for boats to use it. The Ohio & Erie Canal was maintained at a depth of four feet. Here the canal must cross the Cuyahoga River’s largest tributary, Tinkers Creek. Using technology first developed by the Romans, canal engineers made an aqueduct to carry the built waterway over the natural stream. Originally it was a bit farther north. However, shortly after the canal was constructed, Tinkers Creek flooded the aqueduct, proving how unpredictable it can be. The aqueduct was re-built at its present location, but in time suffered more flooding, debris, and leakage. The previous aqueduct was built by the King Iron Bridge Company, but even iron cannot stand against floodwaters. In 2011 the national park replaced it with this concrete one.
audioDescription: Tinkers Creek Aqueduct. 319 words This wayside graphic faces Tinkers Creek which flows through woods and fields to the right to reach the Cuyahoga River. To the left of the panel is a wooden footbridge with metal railings that carries the Towpath Trail over the creek. Farther to the left is a concrete aqueduct which allows the canal to pass over the creek. The aqueduct and the canal have water at this location. To the left of the aqueduct is a modern concrete bridge with guardrails on the scenic byway. Near the graphic on the left is a bench alongside the path. The right side of the panel features a black and white photograph of a worker using a long pole to measure water depth in the creek next to the aqueduct after a flood in 1916. At that time the aqueduct was made of steel truss. The man stands on the outside of the aqueduct balancing on two steel girders. To the right of where he is standing a stream of water is leaking from the aqueduct. The creek bed below has broken logs and smaller debris in it. The caption notes that the steel span lasted nearly 90 years. At lower left is an aerial photograph from 1980 showing the former steel aqueduct. At that time the Canal Road bridge was also made of steel truss. In 1993 the Towpath Trail was built and the Canal Road truss bridge was replaced. Text on the panel reads, “Bridge over Flooding Waters. Aqueducts solve a problem but create other problems. An aqueduct – a water-filled bridge – was built here to carry the canal over Tinkers Creek, the Cuyahoga River’s largest tributary. But the aqueduct leaked and was vulnerable to flood damage. It needed constant repairs. It had to be moved or replaced four times. The present concrete span, built in 2011, replaced the steel aqueduct shown in the two photographs.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125 and hike south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Aqueducts carried water over unpredictable streams, creating a challenge for canal engineers. The Tinkers Creek Aqueduct is one of the only remaining aqueducts on the Ohio & Erie Canal.

title: Waste Weir
listingDescription: The remains found here are called a waste weir, where excess water could drain off the canal. The canal was a regulated 4 feet deep and too much water could do as much damage as too little water.

images.altText: A grey-haired woman in a raincoat stands before a graphic panel along an unpaved trail.
images.title: Waste Weir Photo
images.caption: The “Mud and Muskrats” panel describes the challenges of maintaining the canal.

bodyText: Unlike the nearby Cuyahoga River, the Ohio & Erie Canal was kept at a depth of four feet. Shortly after construction, engineers realized the many challenges of maintaining this consistent water level. More water or less water always seemed to be needed. To reduce flood damage, they built waste weirs such as this one to spill excess water into a channel to the river. To learn more, read the trailside panel.
audioDescription: Waste Weir. 300 words Here on the canal is a graphic panel titled “Mud and Muskrats.” To the left of the panel is a concrete spillway, called a weir, along the edge of the canal. A concrete slab along the top passes over openings. During floods, water can flow through the openings, down the spillway and through a culvert that passes under the towpath. The scenic byway passes close to the canal on the far side, so you may hear vehicles passing. Text on the panel reads, “The Ohio and Erie Canal needed never-ending maintenance. To keep a four-foot depth of water, crews had to patch leaks. Floods and burrowing muskrats were common problems. Crews also had to remove mud from the bottom with shovels and wheelbarrows. Later they used steam-shovel-like dredges. After the canal was built, State of Ohio engineers added special water-control features to handle problems with floodwaters. Here excess water spilled over a dam-like waste weir. A waste way carried the water to the Cuyahoga River. More complex weirs in other locations had gates, but this one did not.” The background of the panel shows a late 1800s photograph of a work crew after dredging mud from the canal bottom. They sit and stand on a canal boat with a steam-shovel extending from its front. At the lower left of the panel is a map showing the log weir and waste way as they appeared in the late 1800s. The current concrete weir was built in the 1906. Originally an open waste channel snaked from the canal to the nearby Cuyahoga River in the lower left of the map. In the upper right of the panel is a photograph of a common muskrat. It has fur in shades of brown with silver tips and a hairless tail. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Lock 39 Trailhead, 8000 Rockside Road, Independence, Ohio 44131 and hike south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: This is one of the few remaining waste weirs along the Ohio & Erie Canal. State of Ohio engineers added special water-control features like this one after the canal opened in the early 1800s. It diverts floodwaters into the Cuyahoga River.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Wetmore Trailhead Information
listingDescription: Wetmore Trailhead offers many choices for exercise and exploration in a less crowded part of the park. Horseback riders and hikers share the five interconnected trails. From here, you can also connect to Kendall Lake and Everett Covered Bridge area trails.

images.altText: A man in a helmet and his brown horse stand in the lot near a trailhead bulletin board.
images.title: Wetmore Trailhead with Horse and Rider
images.caption: Wetmore Trailhead is popular for horseback riding. The lot is setup for trailer parking.

bodyText:
This trailhead got its name from Frederick and Emila Wetmore who farmed here in the late 1800s. In 1958, Tress and Peggy Pittenger bought the property and developed it as Blackacre Farm. Peggy was nationally known for breeding Morgans and Thoroughbreds and for writing books about raising horses. Today’s trails in the Wetmore area follow old horse paths and logging roads established by past owners.

As you explore the area, you’ll see fields of white tubes. Volunteers and staff have planted thousands of young trees here. These will help slow and filter water flowing downstream into the Cuyahoga River. In 2022, the Blackacre Farm buildings were removed as part of the habitat restoration.

In this network of shared trails, hikers and horseback riders can find creeks, woods, wildflowers, and fewer people. The trail surface is unpaved and the landscape is hilly. Trail conditions can be muddy in spring or after a heavy rain. For everyone’s safety, hikers should always yield to horseback riders.

From the bulletin board information panels, you can head in two directions. To the right and across Wetmore Road are the Langes Run, Valley, and Butler’s trails. The Valley Trail continues south to another shared trail network near Everett Covered Bridge. If you turn left at the information board, the downhill path leads to the Wetmore, Valley, and Tabletop trails. From the Wetmore loop, you can cross Quick Road into the Pine Hollow parking lot to link with the hiking trails in the Kendall Lake area. Be aware, this section of the Valley Trail currently ends at Riverview Road, about a mile north of where it branches off the Wetmore Trail.
audioDescription: Wetmore Trailhead. 260 words At the side of the entrance driveway into this parking lot there is a covered kiosk with a bulletin board and a graphic panel. As you face the kiosk, behind you across the driveway is a small building with a rest room. Over your left shoulder is the parking lot. To the left of the kiosk is an unpaved trail that heads down a slope. There is a wooden rail fence enclosing a meadow on the right side of the trail. The other side has overgrown fields and woods. The graphic panel on the kiosk is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location in the southern part of the park indicated. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Wetmore Trailhead. Named after early landowners Frederick and Emila Wetmore, this is the starting point for a trail network shared by hikers and horse-back riders. As you cross through old farm fields, look for signs that the forest is returning. Park volunteers and staff have replanted acres of native trees at Wetmore. This improves wildlife habitat and naturally filters storm water flowing into the Cuyahoga River.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: 4653 Wetmore Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The former Blackacre Farm, nationally known for breeding horses, is gradually returning to nature. Resource management volunteers and staff have planted thousands of trees near Wetmore Trailhead. This reforestation project is part of a larger effort to restore the Cuyahoga River by reducing storm water runoff.

title: William McKinley Tomb
listingDescription: This large circular, domed mausoleum is the final resting place of William McKinley, the 25th president of the United States. McKinley was born in Niles, Ohio but he called Canton home throughout his adult life. He began his career in this city, met his beloved wife, and ran for the highest office of the nation here. His election in 1896 launched an era of Republican dominance that continued until 1910. McKinley governed during a period of intense American expansionism.

images.altText: Large circular, domed marble building surrounded by green lawn.
images.caption: The final resting place for President William J. McKinley, Canton, Ohio.

relatedParks.fullName: William Howard Taft National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: William Howard Taft

bodyText:
This large circular, domed mausoleum is the final resting place of President William McKinley.

McKinley was born in Niles, Ohio but he called Canton home throughout his adult life. In 1861, McKinley enlisted as a private in an Ohio infantry regiment and participated in several Civil War battles. After the war he began his career in this city, met his beloved wife, and ran for the highest office of the nation here. He was the last Civil War veteran elected president. His election in 1896 launched an era of Republican dominance that continued until 1910. McKinley governed during a period of intense American expansionism. Domestically, he supported policies that benefitted American business, including high protective tariffs and deflationary fiscal policies.

On September 6, 1901, an anarchist shot McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York. He died eight days later. After lying in state at the United States Capitol, McKinley’s body returned to Canton.

Mark Hanna, McKinley's lifelong friend, political mentor, and manager, and some of McKinley’s friends immediately began planning a suitable memorial. They chose this site in Canton’s Westlawn Cemetery that McKinley once suggested would be an appropriate location for a soldiers’ and sailors’ memorial. The McKinley National Memorial Association, organized in 1901, purchased the site, and appealed to the public for the $600,000 needed to create the memorial. Construction began in 1905. Nine different States donated materials used in the memorial, completed in 1907. Ida McKinley died that year; she lies next to her husband in the memorial chamber. William McKinley Presidential Library and Museum, a private nonprofit organization under the umbrella of the Stark County Historical Society, administers the memorial and its grounds.

The McKinley Memorial that contains the tomb stands on a grass-covered hill overlooking the city of Canton. Designed by architect H. Van Buren Magonigle, the circular, domed pink granite building rises 96 feet above ground and measures 79 feet in diameter. The double bronze doors of the entrance were the largest in the nation at the time of installation. Originally a long, narrow reflecting pool stretched out from the base of the hill in front of the memorial. This feature, together with the 108 stone steps that lead up to the mausoleum, symbolized the President's sword in time of war. In 1951, a depressed lawn replaced the pool, but the sword effect remains. Midway up the steps is a large bronze statue by Charles Henry Niehaus of President McKinley delivering his last speech in Buffalo.

Colored marble laid in a cross pattern forms the floor of the mausoleum. The bodies of McKinley and his wife lie side by side in two polished, dark-green, granite sarcophagi, resting atop a ten-foot-square of polished dark maroon granite in the center of the space. Their two young daughters are also laid to rest here. Three semi-circular arched bays encircle the central chamber. The entablature and frieze extending around the bottom of the dome contain words from McKinley's last speech.

A project through the Save America's Treasures Grant Program, which helps preserve nationally significant historic properties and collections, funded preservation work at the McKinley Memorial in 2000.
